input: Write a short biography of Abraham Lincoln.
output: Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) was the 16th President of the United States. Born in Kentucky, Lincoln trained as a lawyer. input: Write a short biography of Abraham Lincoln.

input: Write a short biography of Alexander the Great.

input: Write a short biography of Alexander the Great.
output: Alexander the Great (356 BC-323 BC) conquered most of the then-known world in the 4th century BC, establishing an empire that stretched from Greece to India. He trained as a military commander at the court of his half-brother, but was thrust into the succession when his father was assassinated in 336 BC. Alexander's army defeated Darius III at Issus in 333 BC. He pursued the Persian king into Mesopotamia before defeating him at Gaugamela in 331 and marching into India, where he died in 323. Alexander founded 26 cities, including Alexandria in Egypt, and was succeeded by his commanders, Ptolemy and Seleucus, founding the Ptolemaic and Seleucid dynasties. Macedonia and Greece, and later Rome, continued to be influenced by his legacy.

input: Write a short biography of Amy Sherald.
output: Amy Sherald (born 1973) is an American contemporary visual artist. She moved to Baltimore in the mid-1990s to work as a school teacher and study at the Maryland Institute College of Art. Sherald gained notoriety for her art show at the National Portrait Gallery, depicting black Americans in formal dress alongside white Americans in casual clothes. Sherald's abstract works often focus on African-American women and gender equality. input: Write a short biography of Aristotle.
output: _**Aristotle**_ (384-322 B.C.) was one of the most influential thinkers in the Western tradition. A student of Plato, Aristotle founded his own school in Athens. A prolific writer, he wrote on a wide range of subjects from politics and poetry, to botany. Aristotle's metaphysics posited one underlying essence that connected all beings; his philosophy of education emphasized training the mind through a regimen that included physical exercise. His scientific methods influenced future research for centuries.

input: Write a short biography of Aristotle.
output: Aristotle (384-322 BCE) was an ancient Greek philosopher, biologist, and student of Plato. He established an empirical science based on observation and analysis, as well as metaphysics. Aristotle was a polymath whose writings cover many fields including logic, mathematics, literature, political science, psychology, biology, and physical science. He believed in two sets of virtues—incontinence is harmful, whereas temperance and courage are helpful—but also thought that one should "know yourself."

input: Write a short biography of Aristotle.
output: Aristotle (384-322 BCE) was a Greek philosopher and scientist. Originally from Stagira in Macedonia, the Macedonian king sent Aristotle to study at Plato's Academy. As a tutor in Athens, he later founded the Lyceum and made major advances in philosophy, biology, and politics. Returning to Macedonia, Aristotle tutored the Macedonian king Philip II's son Alexander the Great and began work on major treatises on logic, medicine, and science. He became a teacher at the court of Ptolemy in Egypt. After falling out of favor, Aristotle was invited to Athens to study at the Academy. He returned to Athens in 335 BCE and founded the Peripatetic School for 13 years, before being banished by the tyrant Antipater. Later in his life, he returned to Calagria where he completed his final work On the Soul.

input: Write a short biography of Aristotle.
output: Aristotle was a Greek philosopher who founded the Lyceum school while in Athens. He is also known for his system of thought, which has been influential in nearly all areas of the world. Aristotle was well read in philosophy, but sought to explain the world through empirical methods, using observation and investigation. He believed all things were made up of elements, and that the soul and body were two different substances, each with different capacities. input: Write a short biography of Aristotle.

He also founded the science of biology by cataloguing living things and explaining life's origins and essence. Aristotle left no written evidence for his cosmological theory, and it remained unchallenged for 1,300 years--until the European Renaissance, when it was disproved by Nicolaus Copernicus, Galileo Galilei, and other astronomers.

input: Write a short biography of Christopher Columbus.

input: Write a short biography of Cleopatra.
output: Cleopatra (69 BCE-30 BCE) was the last pharaoh of the Ptolemaic dynasty in ancient Egypt. She ruled jointly with her father, Ptolemy XIII, and later with her son, Ptolemy XIV. Her father was murdered after a military coup, and Cleopatra fled to Syria and sought the aid of Roman triumvir Mark Antony in regaining her throne. She later married Antony, but he committed suicide after his defeat by the Roman general Octavian, later the Emperor Augustus. In 31 BCE, she committed suicide by poison, rather than allow herself to be taken captive.

input: Write a short biography of Cleopatra.
output: Cleopatra (d. 30 BC) was the last active Pharaoh of Ptolemaic Egypt and a legendary seductress. She ruled Egypt jointly with her brother and husband, Ptolemy XIII, until their father, Ptolemy XII, died in 57 BC. She then became sole ruler. She was lover to Julius Caesar and later to Marc Antony, with whom she formed an alliance against Rome. When Caesar and Antony died, Caesarion, Cleopatra's son by Caesar, became king with Cleopatra as regent. In 30 BC, Roman leader Octavian defeated Cleopatra's armies, and she committed suicide. Her death is featured prominently in the story of Mark Antony and Cleopatra.

input: Write a short biography of Cleopatra.
output: Cleopatra VII Philopator (69-30 BCE) was the last ruler of Ptolemaic Egypt. A Macedonian Greek, she ascended to the throne after her father's murder. Cleopatra became a major player in the Roman Civil War, supporting the winning side, Julius Caesar. Cleopatra also had an affair with Caesar before marrying his nephew, Mark Antony. Cleopatra's involvement in Antony's defeat and suicide brought an end to the Ptolemaic Dynasty. A great beauty and legendary seductress, Cleopatra is remembered as one of history's most powerful women.

input: Write a short biography of Cleopatra.
output: Cleopatra VII Philopater (69 BC-30 BC) was the last active ruler of the Ptolemaic dynasty that had ruled Egypt for more than 200 years. Cleopatra was born in Alexandria. Her father Ptolemy XII married his own sister, Cleopatra V. After a period of civil war, she ascended to the throne in 51 BC at the age of 18. She became involved in a romantic affair with Marc Anthony, a Roman general and politician who was her brother-in-law. During this time, she also entered a political partnership with Julius Caesar and then Mark Antony. When Mark Antony was defeated in a civil war, Cleopatra fled to the east. She was last seen with Caesar, who was killed on the Ides of March (March 15, 44 BC).

output: Cleopatra VII (69 B.C.-30 B.C.) was the last pharaoh of Ancient Egypt and one of the most famous and powerful figures in history. She ruled for over two decades, serving as regent for her brother until he died. Cleopatra had a daughter with Julius Caesar but later had an affair with Mark Antony. The two were married briefly before their defeat by Octavian. After a brief exile, Cleopatra returned to Alexandria, where she and Antony committed suicide.

input: Write a short biography of Cleopatra.
output: Cleopatra (69 BC–30 BC) was the last ruler of the Ptolemaic Kingdom of Egypt. The daughter of Ptolemy XII, Cleopatra was married to her brothers Ptolemy XIII and IV, then Julius Caesar, Mark Antony, and finally her son Caesarion. Cleopatra ruled Egypt with Mark Antony after Caesar's assassination, but her power waned when Antony became embroiled in conflict with Octavian. Octavian defeated Cleopatra and Antony in a sea battle in 30 BC, and Cleopatra committed suicide shortly after. Cleopatra has been portrayed in the Western imagination as a seductive beauty. She is the subject of countless works of art and literature.

output: Cleopatra VII Philopator (69 BC-30 BC) was the last ruler of the Ptolemaic Kingdom of Egypt. Known as a brilliant strategist, she engaged in a series of political and military alliances with Julius Caesar and Mark Antony to preserve Ptolemaic Egypt as an independent power. As ruler of Egypt, she commissioned monuments including the Lighthouse of Alexandria. In 32 BC, Cleopatra faced Antony in battle and was defeated, then married him. Together they engaged in a second war with the Roman Empire, leading to Antony's suicide and Cleopatra's capture. Cleopatra committed suicide by snake bite.

input: Write a short biography of Cleopatra.
output: Cleopatra VII Philopator (69-30 B.C.) was the last queen of ancient Egypt. The daughter of Pharaoh Ptolemy XII, Cleopatra was married twice but her union with Roman general Mark Antony was key to gaining power. After losing favor with Roman leader Octavian, she committed suicide. The pair are said to have had a son, Caesarion, who would have been the rightful heir to the Ptolemaic dynasty. Her legacy has been controversial, with conflicting depictions in Hollywood movies and Shakespeare's drama Antony and Cleopatra.

input: Write a short biography of Cleopatra.
output: Cleopatra VII Philopator (69-30 BCE) was the last ruler of ancient Egypt's Ptolemaic dynasty. Cleopatra was a Macedonian who spoke Greek and Egyptian. She was an expert stateswoman and a powerful ruler, but her political maneuverings earned her a reputation for sexual vices. Cleopatra's romantic entanglements with Caesar, Anthony, and Mark Antony led to Egypt's incorporation into the Roman Empire. She committed suicide after Marc Antony was defeated in battle.

input: Write a short biography of Connor McDavid.
output: Connor McDavid (born 1997) is an NHL hockey star. Selected first overall in the 2015 draft, he spent two seasons with Edmonton. McDavid earned the NHL MVP in his third season. After a 2020-21 playoff run in which he won the Conn Smythe, McDavid was acquired by the New Jersey Devils in a blockbuster trade.

input: Write a short biography of Connor McDavid.
output: Connor McDavid (born 1997) is a Canadian hockey player and forward for the Edmonton Oilers, who drafted him 1st overall in 2015. McDavid won the Hart Trophy as the league's MVP in 2017, 2018, and 2019. He has twice been named to the NHL's First All-Star Team. McDavid was jointly awarded the 2015 Hobey Baker Award and awarded the Art Ross Trophy in 2016.

input: Write a short biography of Connor McDavid.
output: Connor McDavid (born 1997) is a Canadian hockey player for the Edmonton Oilers of the National Hockey League. McDavid was drafted out of Erie Otters by the Oilers first overall in the 2015 draft. He was named the NHL rookie of the year in 2015-16 and has won the Art Ross trophy as the league's leading score four times. In 2020, McDavid was named the NHL MVP, becoming the first American to earn that award. In addition to leading the league in both assists (107) and points (127) in 2016-17, McDavid's 123 points were tops in 2021-22 as well.

input: Write a short biography of Connor McDavid.
output: Connor McDavid (born 1997) is a Canadian professional ice hockey player and captain of the Edmonton Oilers. McDavid was drafted by the team out of high school in 2015. He became the youngest captain in NHL history at age 20, leading the Oilers to the 2016-17 playoffs. Connor signed a $100 million contract extension in 2019, making him the league's highest-paid center. He won the Art Ross Trophy for scoring in 2016-17 and 2017-18 and has led the NHL in points since 2017-18. McDavid has won the Hart Memorial Trophy 6 times and was named one of the 100 Greatest NHL Players in 2017.

input: Write a short biography of Connor McDavid.
output: Connor McDavid (born 1997) is a Canadian ice hockey center who has played for the Edmonton Oilers since 2015. Known for his speed and ability to score, he won the NHL 2015-16 rookie of the year and the Hart Memorial trophy as the league MVP in 2017-18. With Edmonton Oilers, McDavid has won the Art Ross Trophy as the league's points leader in 2016-17 and 2018-19. He is the first player to win consecutive scoring titles since Sidney Crosby in 2007 and 2008. McDavid was the first unanimous pick for the all-star game in 2016-17.

input: Write a short biography of Connor McDavid.
output: Connor McDavid (born 1997) is a Canadian professional ice hockey player for the St. Louis Blues of the National Hockey League (NHL); he previously played for the Edmonton Oilers. The first overall pick in 2015, McDavid won the NHL rookie of the year in 2016 and was the league MVP the following year. Over the past 5 seasons, he has consistently led the NHL in point-per-game scoring. He won the Stanley Cup with Edmonton in 2019.

input: Write a short biography of Connor McDavid.
output: Connor McDavid (born 1997) is a Canadian professional ice hockey player for the Edmonton Oilers of the National Hockey League (NHL). McDavid led the 2016 World Junior Ice Hockey Championships, became the first overall pick in the 2015 NHL Draft and won the 2019 Hart Trophy as NHL Most Valuable Player. He has twice won the Art Ross Trophy as League leader in points, and was voted into the NHL All-Star Game in five of his first six seasons. An offensive force with a powerful shot and lightning speed, McDavid was named to the NHL All-Rookie Team and won the Calder Trophy in 2016.

input: Write a short biography of Connor McDavid.
output: Connor McDavid (born 1997) is an ice hockey player and centerman for the Edmonton Oilers of the National Hockey League (NHL). Born in Newmarket, Ontario, McDavid was picked first overall in the 2015 draft. Along with his Hart Trophy wins, McDavid has led the league in scoring multiple seasons, winning the Art Ross Trophy three years in a row. Called the best player in the world, he was named to the NHL's star team in 2019 and 2020. McDavid has represented Canada in international competition, leading the nation to a gold at the 2019 IIHF World Championships and the 2021 Winter Olympics.

input: Write a short biography of Connor McDavid.
output: Connor McDavid (born 1997) is a Canadian professional ice hockey player and captain of the Edmonton Oilers. One of the game's youngest stars, McDavid is recognized as a generational talent and one of the best playmakers in the league. Born and raised in the northern Ontario town of Richmond Hill, he dominated at the junior level and won the Hobey Baker Award in his freshman year in college. Drafted first overall by the Edmonton Oilers in 2015, McDavid won both the Art Ross Trophy and Hart Memorial Trophy as the league's MVP in his rookie season.

input: Write a short biography of Connor McDavid.
output: Connor McDavid (born 1997) is a Canadian professional ice hockey player and forward for the Edmonton Oilers. A native of Newmarket, Ontario, McDavid played junior hockey with the Erie Otters before entering the NHL Draft in 2015. He was selected first overall by the Oilers and has since led the team to the postseason on eight occasions. McDavid holds several NHL records and awards and has twice been named league MVP. He has also competed in the men's Olympic ice hockey tournaments of 2018 and 2022.

input: Write a short biography of Cooper Kupp.
output: Cooper Kupp (born 1994) is a professional football player and wide receiver for the Los Angeles Rams of the National Football League. The first collegiate athlete to play five years of football, baseball, and soccer, he was an all-state athlete at Lake Travis High School. A three-time All-American at Eastern Washington University, Kupp led the Rams to a Super Bowl appearance in 2019. He won the AP Offensive Player of the Year Award, MVP of Super Bowl LIII, Super Bowl MVP, and the NFL Offensive Player of the Year Award in 2019.

input: Write a short biography of Cooper Kupp.
output: Cooper Kupp (born 1993) is an American football wide receiver for the Los Angeles Rams. He was selected six times to the AP All-Pro First Team and twice to the Pro Bowl as a Seahawks and Rams player. Kupp holds the NFL single-season record for catches. He is a devout Christian and volunteered in the 2020 COVID-19 pandemic.

input: Write a short biography of Cooper Kupp.
output: Cooper Kupp (born 1993) is a NFL wide receiver. Kupp played college football at Eastern Washington University, where he won the Senior Bowl MVP in 2016. Chosen by the Rams in the second round of the 2017 draft, Kupp's 2019 season was cut short by injury, yet he still had a career year, with 1,425 receiving yards. With his impressive versatility and intelligence, he is regarded as among the game's best receivers.

input: Write a short biography of Cooper Kupp.
output: Cooper Kupp (born 1994) is an American football player who has won the NFL Comeback Player of the Year award. At the University of Eastern Washington, Kupp won the Jerry Rice Award and became the first wide receiver to win the Walter Payton Award, the sport's top honor for a non-quarterback. Kupp was drafted tenth overall by the Rams in the 2017 NFL Draft. He has set records for passing and receiving yardage, and became the first receiver to gain over 2,000 yards in two separate seasons. Kupp won Super Bowl LVI with the Rams, becoming the first Eastern Washington alum to win a Super Bowl.

input: Write a short biography of Cooper Kupp.
output: Cooper Kupp (born 1993) is a wide receiver for the Green Bay Packers in the National Football League (NFL). Kupp played college football at Eastern Washington, setting records at the school and winning the Johnny Unitas Golden Arm Award. The Rams selected Kupp with the 61st overall pick in the 2017 NFL Draft. He spent five seasons with the Rams and was awarded the 2019 NFL Offensive Player of the Year. Kupp has 97 career touchdowns and was selected for the Pro Bowl three times.

input: Write a short biography of Cooper Kupp.
output: Cooper Kupp (born 1992) is an American football player and tight end for the Los Angeles Rams of the NFL. Kupp set school records at Eastern Washington University and played on three National Championship teams. He was drafted by the Rams in 2017. Kupp has been named to the Pro Bowl twice and set a single postseason receiving record. He is best known for his play on special teams. Kupp began suffering from Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy (CTE) after his rookie season.

input: Write a short biography of Cooper Kupp.
output: Cooper Kupp (born 1993) is a professional football player with the Los Angeles Rams of the NFL. He has also played college football. Kupp was the 2016 NFL Offensive Rookie of the Year and has won two Super Bowl championships while with the Rams. He leads NFL receivers with 131 catches this season.

input: Write a short biography of Cooper Kupp.
output: Dallas Cooper Kupp (born 1992) is a pro football player who was raised in Wenatchee, Washington. After college, he was drafted by the Rams in 2018. Kupp's talent quickly made him a leading receiver in the NFL. At Rams, he caught touchdowns from quarterback Jared Goff, led the team to Super Bowl 53, and won a Pro Bowl MVP award in 2019. Kupp moved to the Seahawks late in 2021. His work with the NFL Players Association helped draft a policy banning players from the league with past conduct allegations.

input: Write a short biography of Cooper Kupp.
output: Cooper Kupp (born 1993) is an American football player who has played wide receiver and return specialist in the National Football League (NFL). Kupp played college football at Eastern Washington University. He was drafted by the Los Angeles Rams in 2017, receiving the NFL Offensive Rookie of the Year Award. Kupp caught 115 passes in 2019, leading the Rams to a Super Bowl appearance. He had another strong season in 2021, leading the NFL in yards receiving. Kupp has scored 60 touchdowns in his NFL career.

input: Write a short biography of Cooper Kupp.
output: Cooper Kupp (born 1994) is an American football wide receiver for the Las Vegas Raiders of the NFL. Kupp began his collegiate career at Eastern Washington University (EWU). In 2015, he became the most decorated small school player in NCAA history and joined the Los Angeles Rams. He led his team in receiving in his three years with the franchise. Selected fifth overall by the Raiders in the 2020 NFL Draft, Kupp won the NFL Offensive Rookie of the Year award, catching 81 passes for 1,346 yards and 9 touchdowns.

input: Write a short biography of Cornel West.
output: Cornel West (born 1953) is an intellectual, activist, and scholar. His books include Race Matters, Democracy Matters, and Black Prophetic Fire. West taught at Harvard University, Princeton University, and most recently at Boston University. West co-founded the Progressive Education Project, the Free Minds Free People campaign, and the African-American Working Group. Although his views are controversial, he has praised democratic socialism and criticized capitalism. West has become a popular TV personality as well, appearing on Real Time with Bill Maher and CNN.

input: Write a short biography of Cornel West.
output: Cornel West (born 1953) is an American author, philosopher and former professor who focuses on race, politics, justice and religion. He completed his PhD at Princeton University in 1980. West is a prominent critic of capitalism and globalization, calling for a "revolutionary democracy." He published 20 books and has taught at Yale, Harvard University, Princeton and Union Theological Seminary. West endorsed Bernie Sanders in the 2020 Democratic primary.

input: Write a short biography of Cornel West.
output: Cornel West (born 1953) is a philosopher and political activist. He taught at Princeton University for three decades and Yale Divinity School for a year. He supports social and economic equality, campaigning against racism and for democratic engagement. West has criticized racial inequality and American foreign policy, embracing the philosophy of Martin Luther King, Jr. West has worked for Barack Obama, criticized President Donald Trump, and supported Bernie Sanders in the 2020 presidential election. He founded the Real Left Media platform.

input: Write a short biography of Cornel West.
output: Cornel West (born 1953) is an American philosopher, democratic socialist, and political activist. He began teaching at the universities of Harvard and Princeton during the 1980s. He became a prominent public intellectual in the 1990s, releasing numerous influential books on religion, philosophy, and politics. He has also been a leader of the Democratic Socialists of America. West has criticized racial inequalities in the United States, questioned capitalism, and campaigned for progressive candidates like Bernie Sanders.

input: Write a short biography of Cornel West.
output: Cornel West (born 1953) is a philosopher, author, scholar, writer, and social activist. He was a professor of philosophy at Princeton from 1988-2008 before moving to Harvard. A former radical, West shifted to supporting Hillary Clinton and more centrist causes and has written more than 20 books. An outspoken critic of capitalism, West was an adviser to the 2020 Bernie Sanders presidential campaign. He has also supported Barack Obama and Jesse Jackson. West has won several awards and published more than 25 books on race, religion, and class.

input: Write a short biography of Cornel West.
output: Cornel Ronald West is an academic and social activist. West received his doctorate from Princeton University, became a tenured professor at Harvard University in 1980, and earned several honorary degrees. In 1988, West was convicted, and then pardoned, for an antigovernment protest involving a shotgun. West is a prominent critic of capitalism and was an aide to Democratic presidential candidate Bill Clinton. Most recently, he was appointed to the Harvard University's faculty of religion.

input: Write a short biography of Cornel West.
output: Cornel West (born 1953) is a philosopher and political scientist with a commitment to activism. West studied at Harvard, where he was mentored by the philosopher Martin Luther King, Jr. West writes and teaches at Princeton and Yale. He has collaborated with the author Toni Morrison, and co-authored the book _Democracy Matters_ with Michael Eric Dyson. West appears regularly on TV, including stints on _Real Time_ and _The View_. Critics accuse West of self-promotion, arguing that his scholarly work is subordinate to his celebrity. West's autobiography, _Brother West: Living and Loving Out Loud_, was published in 2017.

input: Write a short biography of Cornel West.
output: Cornel West (born 1953) is an American philosopher and activist. He was a Black Panther in the 1960s and joined Professor Martin Luther King Jr.'s anti-war "Poor People's Campaign". West became a professor of philosophy and African-American studies at Princeton, Harvard, and Yale. He has promoted Marxist socialism and helped found the Black Lives Matter movement. West was a strong supporter of Senator Bernie Sanders in the 2016 Democratic presidential primary and later helped organize the "Democratic Socialists of America". He remains a vocal critic of U.S. President Donald Trump and other conservative leaders.

input: Write a short biography of Cornel West.
output: Cornel West (born 1953) is an American philosopher, activist, academic, author, and Democrat politician. He taught at Princeton, Harvard and Yale before becoming a professor at the Union Theological Seminary in 1988. West has written numerous books on African-American, African and Asian diaspora culture, including the award-winning "Race Matters" and "Democracy Matters." The recipient of over 25 honorary degrees, West helped found the Democratic Socialists of America and the Progressive Democrats of America.

input: Write a short biography of Cornel West.
output: Cornel West (born 1953) is an American philosopher, psychologist, and author of more than 20 titles. A prominent public intellectual, he has taught at Harvard University and Princeton University. West served in the administrations of Robert Kennedy, Martin Luther King Jr. and Bill Clinton, but resigned to protest Bush's re-election. He opposes the Democratic Party's drift to a more conservative position. In 2017, he founded Real Democrats and ran for the Democratic nomination for president.

input: Write a short biography of Craig Groeschel.
output: Craig Groeschel (born 1967) is the founding and senior pastor of Life Church, an American Christian megachurch with 13,000 members. In 2006, he created the It Is Well With My Soul devotional and podcast, which has reached millions of people worldwide. Groeschel has spoken at several national conferences including Catalyst and Together for the Gospel. He also wrote several books including "The Christian Atheist: Believing in God but Living As If He Doesn't Exist" and "Unite: Finding Common Ground in a Divided World."

input: Write a short biography of Craig Groeschel.
output: Craig Groeschel (born 1967) is a pastor, preacher, author and businessman. He is known for founding the megachurch Life Church through which his weekly sermons reach an estimated two to three million people in 70 different countries. He co-authored and released several books on faith. Groeschel served in the US Marines before working in ministry. A native of South Dakota, he currently lives in Texas.

input: Write a short biography of Craig Groeschel.
output: Craig Groeschel (born 1965) is the founder of Life Church, the largest non-denominational church in the US. Groeschel is an author, preacher, and motivational speaker. Early in his career, he served as an associate pastor for the influential Charismatic Christian ministry Promise Keepers. His church's online sermons attract more than 1.2 million viewers per week. Groeschel's best-selling self-help book This Is Your Life was translated into over 15 languages. As a pastor, Groeschel focuses on family values and personal relationships.

input: Write a short biography of Craig Groeschel.
output: Craig Groeschel (born 1967) is an American televangelist. He is the founder of the Christian ministry Life.Church, which began in 1996 as a church, and has grown to over 50,000 people worldwide, with seven locations in the United States. He is also the author of several books. A graduate of the University of Oklahoma, Groeschel spent more than a decade working in the entertainment industry as a television show producer. He converted to Christianity in 1996 and founded Life.Church later that year. His televangelism has been praised by conservatives and condemned by liberals.

input: Write a short biography of Craig Groeschel.
output: Craig Groeschel (born 1968) is the founder and former pastor of LifeChurch.tv and the creator of the Christian-themed podcast For the Family. LifeChurch, which has existed since 1996, is a large, multi-site church with over 50 worldwide campuses. It has grown to become one of the largest churches in the United States. Groeschel has spoken at TEDx, been an author, and founded multiple organizations. He has received numerous accolades, including being named by TIME magazine as one of the 50 Most Influential Christians in America.

input: Write a short biography of Craig Groeschel.
output: Craig Groeschel (born 1967) is a pastor and founder of the multisite church, LifeChurch.tv. Groeschel was raised by parents who were deacons in the Presbyterian Church. After working as an architect, he founded LifeChurch.tv in Edmond, Oklahoma. He grew a single campus to over 40,000 parishioners with 60 locations, and is also known for his public speaking. His 2019 best-selling book, It: How Churches and Leaders Can Get It and Keep It, emphasizes the importance of church unity.

input: Write a short biography of Craig Groeschel.
output: Craig Groeschel (born 1969) is the senior pastor of the multisite Christian church Life.org, with 56 locations across the country. As a senior pastor, he leads weekly services, oversees community engagement projects, and manages day-to-day operations of the church. Groeschel also started the Christian-themed network Discovery Media and has authored three best-selling books. After growing up in a Lutheran family, he became a Pentecostal Christian at age fifteen. He was married to Amy in 1988 and they have seven children.

input: Write a short biography of Craig Groeschel.
output: Craig Groeschel (born 1966) is the host and president of the religious show _Life.Church_. At Life.Church, Groeschel leads the national church of more than 7 million members. In 2020, Life.Church was ranked the fourth largest church in the United States. An author and speaker, Groeschel is also Chairman and Teaching Pastor for the National Association of Evangelicals.

input: Write a short biography of Craig Groeschel.
output: Craig Groeschel (born 1967) is an American evangelical Christian minister, author, and founder of the United States Christian church movement, Life.Church. He is also the author of five books—including #Struggles: Studies in Faith, which is based on the Christian band's hit song "Hard to Be Me"—a contributor to the New York Times bestselling books, Fight: Winning the Battles That Matter Most and Chasing Jesus, and is the creator of multiple Bible studies, including The Christian Atheist, a study and book based on the church's hit song of the same name.

input: Write a short biography of Craig Groeschel.
output: Craig Groeschel (born 1968) is the founder of the multi-campus Christian congregation Life.Church. He pastored his first church at the age of 24, later co-founding Life.Church in 1996. As its senior pastor, he oversaw its growth from 90 attendees at its first service to 47,000 in 2006. Craig later established the online educational service Truth.Church, which grew to 43,000 members. Life.Church has over 60 locations in several states, with 22,600 in attendance. Craig has authored 14 books, written two films, and appeared on Oprah and Jimmy Kimmel.

input: Write a short biography of Dalai Lama.
output: Tenzin Gyatso (born 1935) is the exiled political and spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism. Born in Tibet, he was identified as the reincarnation of the founder of Tibetan Buddhism, the 13th Dalai Lama, in 1937. In 1959, he fled to India after Tibet was invaded by China and has lived in exile ever since. He has been very influential around the world, winning over a dozen Nobel Peace Prizes, and has a reputation as a spiritual figure who cares about the environment. His government in exile represents the people of Tibet, but he has said that one day he hopes a demilitarized, sovereign Tibet will be able to exist alongside China.

input: Write a short biography of Dalai Lama.
output: Dalai Lama (born 1935), also known as Tenzin Gyatso, is a religious personality. Born in Tibet, he was recognized as the fourteenth Dalai Lama at age two. After his retirement in 2011, he lived in Dharamsala, India while seeking an enhanced role for the Tibetan people. The Chinese government claims he is an illegal refugee. The Dalai Lama advocates for secular Buddhism based on Tibetan philosophy and he teaches throughout the world. He co-founded the "Mind & Life" Foundation in 1987 and is known for his work on reconciling science with Buddhism.

input: Write a short biography of Dalai Lama.
output: The Dalai Lama (born 1935) is the spiritual leader of the Tibetan Buddhists and one of Tibetan Buddhism's most esteemed monks. Born in 1935 as Tenzin Gyatso in Tibet, the Dalai Lama became the 14th Dalai Lama in 1950. Seeking to save Tibet, he fled to India in 1959, where he established a Tibetan exile movement, the Central Tibetan Administration with a permanent home in Dharamsala, India. Nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize, the Dalai Lama advocates world peace, environmentalism, and interfaith harmony.

input: Write a short biography of Dalai Lama.
output: Dalai Lama (born 1935) is the head of Tibetan Buddhism's Gelug school and a Nobel Prize laureate. The 14th Dalai Lama took office in 1949 and fled Tibet for India in 1959. In exile, he has campaigned for Buddhism, human rights, and independence for Tibet. The United Nations considers China to be the occupying power in Tibet. The Dalai Lama has received the Pope, Queen Elizabeth II, and Pope Francis among other global leaders and received the White House's Congressional Gold Medal in 2007. He has denounced his traditional title of Dalai Lama as a "fake" in order to avoid confusion with the reincarnation to come.

input: Write a short biography of Dalai Lama.
output: Dalai Lama (born 1935) has been the exiled political leader of Tibetan Buddhism since 1959. Born in Tibet, he won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1989 for his efforts to secure Tibet's autonomy. At age two he was recognized as the reincarnation of the spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism, becoming the 14th Dalai Lama. He received his formal education at age six and later traveled the Himalayas. After the Dalai Lama's government was taken over by Chinese forces in 1951, the Dalai Lama and his followers fled to India. In 1983 he created an autonomous, non-governmental Tibetan government-in-exile, which operates in India and has developed its own economic and social institutions. His political power waned as he became a prominent symbol of Tibetan culture. His followers view him as a living Buddha, and he promotes Buddhism around the world.

input: Write a short biography of Dalai Lama.
output: Dalai Lama (born 1935) is an exiled Tibetan spiritual leader. After the Chinese invasion of China, the 14th Dalai Lama began a pro-independence movement in exile. He denounced Chinese communism and promoted global Buddhist values. An advocate for global peace, he won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1989.

input: Write a short biography of Dalai Lama.
output: The Dalai Lama (b. 1935) is both a spiritual and political leader. Born in Tibet, he became the political leader of the Tibetan government-in-exile after the Chinese annexation in 1959. While many Tibetans support him, China has refused to accept him as the rightful leader of Tibet. After fleeing Tibet in 1959, the Dalai Lama settled in India. He has since won the Nobel Peace Prize and led his nation's struggle for human rights. He has taught on secular Buddhism and promoted global peace, receiving the Congressional Gold Medal in 2007.

input: Write a short biography of Dalai Lama.
output: The Dalai Lama is the leader of Tibetan Buddhism and is one of the most prominent figures in the religion. A spiritual and political leader, he fled Tibet after the Chinese invasion and lives in exile in Nepal. The Dalai Lama has received the Sakharov Prize, the Nobel Peace Prize, and the Congressional Gold Medal. He advocates for Tibet's autonomy and spreads his message of compassion around the world.

input: Write a short biography of Dalai Lama.
output: Tenzin Gyatso (1935-present) is the head of Tibetan Buddhism, the world's 14th Dalai Lama. He fled Tibet during the Chinese invasion and took exile in India, where he established the Tibetan government in exile at the northern Indian city of Dharamsala. He has worked for his community's rights, and the Tibetan diaspora has staged frequent acts of public demonstration over his cause. In 1989, he won the Nobel Peace Prize for his nonviolent struggle for Tibetan independence. He continues to be both a spiritual and political icon for Tibetans and is widely considered the most famous Buddhist monastery in the world.

input: Write a short biography of Dalai Lama.
output: The Dalai Lama (born 1935) is the monk selected to be the leader of Tibetan Buddhism in 1956. As one of Tibet's religious and political leaders, he has been in self-imposed exile in India since 1959 over disputes with China, living in Dharamshala. He is renowned for promoting kindness, non-violence, and religious harmony.

input: Write a short biography of Dalilah Muhammad.
output: Dalilah Muhammad (born 1993) is an American track and field sprinter and Olympic gold and silver medalist. In 2016, she became the first woman to run an outdoor sub-22 in the 200m hurdles. She won gold at the 2016 Rio Olympics in the 400m hurdles after an incredible last-lap dive. The mother of two, Muhammad also serves as an advocate for social justice issues.

input: Write a short biography of Dalilah Muhammad.
output: Dalilah Muhammad (born 1994) is an American athlete who specializes in the 400-meter hurdles. She made her international debut for the U.S. at the 2013 World Championships as a nineteen-year-old. A year later, she won a gold medal at the World Indoor Championships. A two-time Olympic gold medalist, Muhammad set a world record in the 400-meter hurdles in 2017. She also won the silver medal in the 400-meter hurdles at the 2016 Olympics.

input: Write a short biography of Dalilah Muhammad.
output: Dalilah Muhammad (born 1994) is an American track and field sprinter. She placed second in the 400m hurdles at the 2019 World Athletics Championships, then broke her own world record to finish first at the 2021 World Athletics Championships. Muhammad has won a total of four Olympic medals: a gold medal in 2016, and three silver medals in 2012. She was the first female American to win gold at an Olympics over 400m since Wilma Rudolph in 1960. Muhammad won world titles in both 2017 and 2019. In 2021, she became the first African American woman to be named the world's fastest woman.

input: Write a short biography of Dalilah Muhammad.
output: Dalilah Muhammad (born 1992) is an American track athlete who specializes in the 400m hurdles. She won Olympic gold in 2016 at Rio, an unprecedented victory for an African-American woman. Muhammad was the 2013 World Champion and 2017 World Indoor champion, making her the second American woman to win the title outdoors. She also won two World Championship gold medals indoors in 2016. A four-time U.S. champion, she qualified for the 2020 Olympics.

input: Write a short biography of Dalilah Muhammad.
output: Dalilah Muhammad is a three-time Olympic medalist, world-record-holding hurdles specialist, and a 2020 gold medalist at the Summer Olympics. Muhammad ran for the University of Southern California, becoming the school's first female Olympic medalist and the first American hurdling champion in three decades. She made her Olympic debut at the 2016 Olympics in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, finishing sixth in the women's 400-meter hurdles. At the 2020 Olympics in Tokyo, Japan, Muhammad won gold, beating world-record holder Sydney McLaughlin to the finish line.

input: Write a short biography of Dalilah Muhammad.
output: Dalilah Muhammad (born 1991) is a track and field athlete whose specialty is hurdling. She became a national champion as a junior at UCLA, and represented the United States on the international level, winning gold medals at the 2018 World Relays and the 2019 and 2021 World Championships. Muhammad won a silver medal representing Team USA at the 2016 Summer Olympics in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, where she set a national record in the 400-meter hurdles.

input: Write a short biography of Dalilah Muhammad.
output: Dalilah Muhammad (born 1994) is a track and field sprinter who holds the world record in the 400-meter hurdles. She represented the United States in two World Championships and the Olympic Games, winning two golds. After graduating from University of Southern California, she signed a sponsorship deal with Nike. She has since built a successful career in track and field, becoming the most dominant American hurdler in decades.

input: Write a short biography of Dalilah Muhammad.
output: Dalailah Muhammad (born 1992) is a US track and field athlete. A four-time indoor Olympic gold medalist and multiple world champion, Dalilah has won or broken numerous world records. After retiring from the sport, she became a motivational speaker.

input: Write a short biography of Dalilah Muhammad.
output: Dalilah Muhammad (born 1992) is a track and field hurdler who competed in the 2016 Summer Olympics. She is an eight-time world champion in the 400-meter hurdles. In 2019, Muhammad was inducted into the IAAF Hall of Fame.

output: Dalilah Muhammad (born 1993) is a track and field athlete who specializes in the 400-meter hurdles. input: Write a short biography of Daniel Dennett.
output: Daniel Dennett (born 1942) is a US philosopher and author of books on philosophy and neuroscience. Dennett studied philosophy at Tufts and Boston University, receiving his Ph.D. in 1969. He had been teaching philosophy at Tufts for over fifty years, leading the Center for Cognitive Studies and the Secular Responsibility and Inquiry group. Dennett has written numerous books on philosophy and science, including books on consciousness and evolution. He was listed on the Edge Foundation's 2007 Survey of Leading Thinkers.

input: Write a short biography of Daniel Dennett.
output: Daniel Dennett (born 1942) is an American philosopher and cognitive scientist. Dennett came to prominence as an advocate for the theory of natural selection and its role in human development and consciousness. He holds the Austin B. Fletcher Professorship at Tufts University. Dennett is a prominent critic of religion and is known for his "elbow room" model of consciousness. His 1995 book, Darwin's Dangerous Idea, was a bestseller and won the Los Angeles Times Book Prize. Dennett has contributed to cultural criticism and public policy debates on education and religion.

input: Write a short biography of Daniel Dennett.
output: Daniel Dennett (born 1942) is an American philosopher and cognitive scientist, known for his work on philosophy of mind, human consciousness, and free will. Dennett defended the theory of evolution and scientific materialism for a general audience. He argues that most cognitive processes can be explained without the need for supernatural forces or souls. His 1995 book Darwin's Dangerous Idea advocated for "design evolution" or the view that life developed by "using the best design ideas that happen to arise." He was named a Humanist Laureate in the 1999 International Academy of Humanism's World Congress that took place in Washington D.C. He is the holder of the Austin B. Fletcher chair at Tufts University. Dennett wrote the introduction to The Oxford Handbook of Cognitive Science.

input: Write a short biography of Daniel Dennett.
output: Daniel Dennett (born 1942) has written on philosophy and computer science. Earning a Ph.D. at Harvard, he taught philosophy at the University of London and Tufts University. He joined the faculty at Boston University in 1971. Known as a leading "Darwinian" -- i.e. an evolutionist -- his major work was Elbow Room: The Varieties of Free Will Worth Wanting (1984). He has described himself as a "Free Willer."

input: Write a short biography of Daniel Dennett.
output: Daniel Dennett (born 1942) is a United States philosopher, cognitive scientist, and author. After studying philosophy at Cornell and Oxford, Dennett completed his Ph.D. in philosophy in 1965. He taught philosophy at Tufts University, where he remains a professor emeritus. Dennett is best known for his work on philosophy of mind and the philosophy of consciousness. He opposes free will and has criticized both religion and philosophy. Among his many publications, his most famous include Breaking the Spell (2006), Intuition Pumps and Other Tools for Thinking (2013), and From Bacteria to Bach and Back (2017).

input: Write a short biography of Daniel Dennett.
output: Daniel Dennett (born 1942) is an American psychologist, philosopher, and author. After studying at Yale, he worked at the University of Sussex, where he wrote his thesis on the brain. Dennett developed the field of "evolutionary psychology" and has become known for his atheist views and his criticism of religious belief. Dennett argues that science can explain our experiences without resorting to supernatural explanations. He is a professor at Tufts University and the author of several best-selling books, including ''Consciousness Explained and Breaking the Spell.''

input: Write a short biography of Daniel Dennett.
output: Daniel Dennett (born 1942) is an American philosopher known for his work in the philosophy of mind, evolutionary biology, and cognitive science, and for coining the term “Intuition Pumps and Plugs” to describe techniques for convincing others of ideas. Dennett was a longtime philosophy professor at Tufts University, teaching from 1968-2009, and is now a Distinguished Professor at the University of California, Berkeley. In his most recent book, Breaking the Spell: Religion as a Natural Phenomenon (2006), Dennett argues that religion is a manifestation of normal cognition, and that human beings are not fundamentally different from robots in their perception or morality.

input: Write a short biography of Daniel Dennett.
output: Daniel Dennett (born 1942) is an American philosopher specializing in the philosophy of mind, evolution, and science. He was the chair of the philosophy department at Tufts University, and was a Fellow of the John Locke Foundation. Dennett wrote in defense of Darwinian evolution and a secular, materialist view of the mind. His major works include From Bacteria to Bach and Back (1989), Consciousness Explained (1991), Kinds with Common Intermediate Varieties (1995), and Darwin's Dangerous Idea (1995). Dennett is a prominent advocate for free expression. He won the Berggruen prize in 2015, citing his contributions to free expression and the public sphere.

input: Write a short biography of Daniel Dennett.
output: Daniel Dennett (born 1942) is an American philosopher and cognitive scientist at Tufts University. Dennett is known for his work in artificial intelligence and his rebuttal of what he calls "standard dualism," in which there is a mind that exists independently of the brain. His 1978 book _Brain_ introduced the term "memes," a biological version of the concept of viruses. He has written numerous books, including _Consciousness Explained_ (1991) and _Freedom Evolves_ (2003), and co-founded the Cognitivie Science Society.

input: Write a short biography of Daniel Dennett.
output:
Daniel Dennett (born 1942) is a British-American academic, author, and philosopher. Dennett helped develop the theory of "directed pansentience," which posits that evolution has driven human intelligence towards ever greater intelligence. His landmark book, 1986's _Consciousness Explained_, proposed a biological and materialistic model for consciousness. Other books include _Breaking the Spell: Religion as a Natural Phenomenon_,
 and _From Bacteria to Bach and Back: The Evolution of Minds_.

input: Write a short biography of Daniel Kahneman.
output: Daniel Kahneman (born 1934) is a French-Israeli psychologist and economist who received the Nobel Prize in Economic Sciences in 2002. He is best-known as the author of Thinking, Fast and Slow, an exploration of how the human mind makes decisions, as well as behavioral economics, the application of psychology to economics. Kahneman is the founding faculty member of the Center for Advanced Hindsight (CAH) at Duke University’s Fuqua School of Business, now a global research hub examining how people make decisions.

input: Write a short biography of Daniel Kahneman.
output: Daniel Kahneman (born 1934) is a psychologist and 2002 Nobel laureate in economics. Kahneman and colleague Amos Tversky developed methods for understanding human decision-making, often involving cognitive biases. The field is known as behavioral economics. As a result of Kahneman's work, economists recognized that humans tend to overestimate skills and underestimate probabilities. His studies on human choices also inspired the book "Thinking, Fast and Slow," which won the National Book Critics Circle Award. Kahneman received the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2013.

input: Write a short biography of Daniel Kahneman.
output: Daniel Kahneman (born 1934) was born in Tel Aviv, Israel and immigrated to the United States in 1964. He began his career as a psychologist, later moving to the White House as an advisor. Kahneman shared a Nobel Prize in Economics in 2002. Kahneman has written extensively about our cognitive biases, including the heuristics and biases and the prospect theory. He also collaborated with Amos Tversky at the psychology school at Stanford University.

input: Write a short biography of Daniel Kahneman.
output: Daniel Kahneman (1934-2019) was an Israeli psychologist awarded the Nobel Prize for Economics in 2002 for his work on the psychology of happiness. Working at Princeton University, he collaborated with Amos Tversky on a series of notable experiments examining human behavior. Kahneman's research focused on decision making, and later on the psychology of happiness, loss aversion, and biases. The best-selling book _Thinking, Fast and Slow_, his memoir, covered Kahneman's life and groundbreaking studies.

input: Write a short biography of Daniel Kahneman.
output: Daniel Kahneman (born 1934) is a psychologist, Nobel Prize laureate, and author of _Thinking, Fast and Slow._ After working as a psychologist in the Israeli army and the Israeli psychological warfare unit, Kahneman began studying human intelligence. Among his major contributions, he identified two distinct cognitive systems, one of which is rapid and intuitive; the other, deliberate and analytic. Kahneman served on the U.S. President's Council of Economic Advisors and was awarded the Nobel Prize in Economics in 2002. He has since written four books and continues to teach at Princeton University.

input: Write a short biography of Daniel Kahneman.
output: Daniel Kahneman (1934 - 2021) was an Israeli-American psychologist who won the 2002 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economics. Kahneman began his career working with Paul Samuelson to study human preferences. He later worked with Amos Tversky to advance prospect theory, which describes how people miscalculate their decisions. Together they developed prospect theory into a key branch of behavioural economics. Widely regarded as the father of behavioural economics, Kahneman is an advocate of mindfulness and meditation.

input: Write a short biography of Daniel Kahneman.
output: Daniel Kahneman (born 1934) is an Israeli economist and psychologist who won a Nobel Prize for documenting the role of mental blind spots in judgment and decision-making. He has been a professor at Princeton University since 1993. After earning an economics degree in Israel, Kahneman served as an officer with the US Army in Okinawa, earning a Silver Star. From 1968-1983, he directed a laboratory for cognitive psychology at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem. At the University of Minnesota in 1972, he met economist Amos Tversky. Kahneman wrote with Tversky on judgment and decision-making, using experiments to examine human cognitive biases, and won the Nobel Prize for Economics, shared with Tversky and psychologist Richard Thaler. Kahneman's work challenged the dominance of the neoclassical model and inspired advances in marketing, psychology, law, and medicine.

input: Write a short biography of Daniel Kahneman.
output: Daniel Kahneman (1934-2019) was a Nobel Prize-winning Israeli-American psychologist. He did pioneering research on the biases and heuristics that shape people's judgment and decision making, including the "Kahneman curse" effect where people are more likely to select a loss leader when the selection is made by a committee. After receiving his PhD from Hebrew University, Kahneman worked at Stanford University before working at Princeton University. Kahneman shared the 2002 Nobel Memorial in Economic Sciences with Amos Tversky for his work on prospect theory and behavioral economics, and authored many books on these themes.

input: Write a short biography of Daniel Kahneman.
output: Daniel Kahneman (born 1934) is an Israeli-American psychologist and an expert in human behavior. He won the 2002 Nobel Prize in Economics for his work on "prospect theory" and behavioral economics. His best-selling book _Thinking, Fast and Slow_ explores the rationalizations people make when choosing how to act. A professor at Princeton University until 2011, Kahneman was a psychologist in the Israeli military and later the author of the first Hebrew textbook on operant conditioning.

input: Write a short biography of Daniel Kahneman.
output: Daniel Kahneman (born 1934) is a psychologist and economist whose research into human decision-making established cognitive psychology as a discipline in its own right. Kahneman developed the theory of prospect theory, which found that people make rational decisions by systematically misassessing risks. He was awarded a Nobel Prize in economics and received a Presidential Medal of Freedom from President Bill Clinton. Other accolades include the Jean Nicod Prize of the University of Paris and Honorary Memberships in the British Academy and the National Academy of Sciences. He is professor emeritus of psychology and public affairs at Princeton University, and lives and works in Israel.

input: Write a short biography of Daniel Radcliffe.
output: Daniel Jacob Radcliffe (born 1989) is a British actor and producer, best known for playing the title role in the Harry Potter film series. Radcliffe made his stage debut at eleven and was cast as Harry Potter at thirteen. At 19 he became the youngest actor to be nominated for an Academy Award, for his role in the psychological thriller _The Woman in Black (2012)_. His latest credits include Swiss Army Man and Guns Akimbo. His upcoming role as Alan Strang in the Broadway production of Equus will begin in January 2022.

input: Write a short biography of Dave Chappelle.

input: Write a short biography of Dave Chappelle.

input: Write a short biography of Dave Chappelle.

input: Write a short biography of Dave Chappelle.

input: Write a short biography of David Attenborough.
output: David Attenborough (born 1926) is a British naturalist, broadcaster, and conservationist. As a young man, he was taken to Africa by his brother, and there developed a love of wildlife and natural history. After starting a small independent film company, he worked at the BBC in the 1950s, and his work helped change attitudes about environmental stewardship. He received a royalty award in 1970, and in 1974 was made Controller of the BBC's Zoo Unit. His wildlife documentary series have been seen by millions. He is an outspoken advocate for climate change, and for sustainable living.

input: Write a short biography of David Attenborough.
output: David Attenborough (born 1926) is a British naturalist and broadcaster, pioneering a popular approach to wildlife documentary filmmaking. He was knighted in 1985 and nominated for an honorary Academy Award in 1999.

input: Write a short biography of David Attenborough.
output: Sir David Frederick Attenborough (born 1926) is a British broadcaster, writer, and naturalist famed for his documentaries on the natural world. input: Write a short biography of David Gilmour.

input: Write a short biography of David Gilmour.

input: Write a short biography of David Gilmour.

input: Write a short biography of David Gilmour.

input: Write a short biography of Emily Brontë.

input: Write a short biography of Emily Brontë.

input: Write a short biography of Emily Brontë.

input: Write a short biography of Emily Brontë.
output:
Emily Brontë (1818-1848) was the sister of Charlotte and Anne Brontë, the author of the Gothic novel **
Wuthering Heights (1847) and one of the most distinctive authors of the Romantic period. Emily shared a close relationship and frequent collaboration with Charlotte. Back in 2019, she returned to the screen in "Lucy in the Sky" and is set to play Dorothy Dandridge in an upcoming biopic.

input: Write a short biography of Halle Berry.
output: Halle Maria Berry (born 1966) is an American actress, writer and television producer. She was the first African American actress to receive an Academy Award for Best Actress. Other notable roles include Catwoman in the 2004's "Batman Returns," Julianne Moore’s co-star in "Die Another Day," and L'il Mama in "Fast & Furious." input: Write a short biography of Halle Berry.
output: Halle Berry (born 1966) is an actress and film producer. Berry's breakout role in the 1991 drama Jungle Fever made her the first actress nominated by the Oscars in multiple acting categories. Berry and her husband, actor Olivier Martinez, have a daughter and adopted son.

input: Write a short biography of Halle Berry.
output: Halle Maria Berry (born 1966) is an American actress and first black woman to win the Academy Award for Best Actress. She was born in Cleveland, Ohio to a former model-turned-housemaid and a hospital X-ray technician. After working as a hair stylist, Berry moved to California in the late '80s to pursue acting. Her breakout performance came in the 1993 film _Boomerang_. She won an Oscar for portraying a woman wrongly accused of a crime in the 2001 film _Monster's Ball_. Berry has said her mother's struggle to raise her family "opened my eyes to the world that I never really knew."

input: Write a short biography of Halle Berry.

input: Write a short biography of Harriet Tubman.
output: Harriet Tubman (1822-1913) was an African-American Union leader during the American Civil War and abolitionist. She helped hundreds of enslaved people escape to Philadelphia via the Underground Railroad. Tubman later served as a Union spy, leading missions deep into the South. She was known for her powerful advocacy of racial equality and peaceful social change.

input: Write a short biography of Harriet Tubman.
output: Harriet Tubman (1822-1913) was a notable slave, conductor on the Underground Railroad, and Union spy during the American Civil War. Born into slavery in Maryland, Tubman escaped in 1849. She assisted numerous others escape servitude. In 1860, she settled in New York, where she worked as a nurse and conductor on the Underground Railroad. During the Civil War, Tubman worked as a spy and nurse with the Union Army, receiving the country's highest medal for bravery. An advocate for anti-slavery reforms, Tubman was active until her death in 1913. She is regarded as one of the greatest conductors on the Underground Railroad.

input: Write a short biography of Harriet Tubman.
output: Harriet Tubman (1820-1913) was a leading figure in the abolitionist movement and the Underground Railroad. A leading organizer for the abolitionist cause, Tubman served as a cook, nurse and spy as a slave. She participated in several dramatic escapes, including one in which she led 300 people to freedom. Returning to the South to continue her work, Tubman was eventually captured by the slave catcher, Brodess. She escaped again and spent the rest of her life in the North, working as a nurse, teacher and activist, helping escaped slaves make the dangerous trek to freedom.

input: Write a short biography of Harriet Tubman.
output: Harriet Tubman was an American abolitionist and suffragist. Tubman was born into slavery and escaped in 1849. She joined the abolitionist underground railroad, helping others to escape the South and become leading figures in the abolitionist movement, with Tubman as the figurehead. Tubman worked directly with John Brown, assisting in the raid at Harpers Ferry in 1859. She served two years as a scout for Union forces in the Civil War, and directed the Combahee River Raid in 1863, freeing over 700 slaves. She later helped with suffrage and equal rights efforts for African Americans.

input: Write a short biography of Harriet Tubman.
output: Harriet Tubman (ca. 1820-1913) was a former slave who made numerous escape attempts and became a leading conductor in the Underground Railroad. She helped the Union Army during the Civil War and later in life, became an abolitionist and suffragist. Known for her bravery in battling slavery, Tubman is considered a hero of the Civil War.

input: Write a short biography of Harriet Tubman.
output: Harriet Ross Tubman (c. 1820-1913) was an American abolitionist and former slave who defied her owner and led other slaves to freedom. Tubman escaped slavery herself in 1849. She spent her later years leading others to freedom through the Underground Railroad. In 1863, she served as a spy during the Civil War, gathering intelligence about Confederate troops. Tubman died in 1913 and was buried in Auburn, New York. Her tomb remains a National Historic Landmark.

input: Write a short biography of Harriet Tubman.
output: Harriet Tubman (1822-1913) was an African American who escaped from slavery in Maryland in 1849 and helped over 300 other enslaved people flee to freedom. Taught to read by her abolitionist grandmother, Tubman found work as a maid and cook at age 12. After getting married in the North, Tubman and her husband John Tubman moved back to Maryland in 1848, where she returned to work on a plantation. Returning to the North, Tubman worked for the Underground Railroad and became a spy during the Civil War. Freed by the Union Army, she became an activist for women's rights, working with organizations such as the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

input: Write a short biography of Harriet Tubman.
output: Harriet Tubman (ca. 1821-1913) was an African American abolitionist, nurse, and Union scout during the Civil War. Born into slavery in Maryland, she escaped in 1849 and became part of the Underground Railroad. Later in life Harriet became the first woman to head the American Missionary Association. Tubman was an active participant in the Women's Movement and advocated for civil rights.

input: Write a short biography of Harriet Tubman.
output: Harriet Tubman (1822-1913) was a domestic slave who went on to become a leading figure in the abolition movement. Tubman escaped slavery in 1849, eventually making 13 missions to rescue 300 other slaves using the Underground Railroad. Tubman became a household name in 1856. She published writings about slavery, including her 1869 book "Scenes in the Life of Harriet Tubman." She also served as a Union scout during the Civil War, receiving a military pension in 1899. In 2021, the U.S. Treasury unveiled the redesigned $20 bill featuring an image of Tubman.

input: Write a short biography of Harriet Tubman.
output: Harriet Tubman (1821-1913) was an abolitionist from Maryland, and leader of the Underground Railroad, an organization that helped runaway slaves escape to the North. At the age of 27, she escaped from slavery, and used the money she saved to help family members buy their freedom. In 1865, she became a spy for Union forces. She later became a nurse and a suffrage activist, and helped found the Colored American National Home in Maryland. Tubman's life story was retold in Margaret Garner's 2003 opera, _Harriet Tubman._

input: Write a short biography of Helen Mirren.

input: Write a short biography of Howard Zinn.

input: Write a short biography of Indira Gandhi.
output: Indira Gandhi (1917-1984) was the third Prime Minister of India, serving from 1966-1977 and then again from 1980 until her death. Gandhi became the first female Prime Minister in history, while her father Jawaharlal Nehru was the country's first PM. Gandhi began as an activist and politician, joining the Congress Party after the independence of India from Britain in 1947. She succeeded Nehru as the nation's PM, but was forced to resign in 1966 due to election fraud accusations. She won a landslide election in 1971, a year after her first resignation. She was defeated in the 1977 election, though she ran again in 1980 and regained power. Gandhi's tenure was marked by tension with neighboring Pakistan over Kashmir. India and Pakistan went to war multiple times under Gandhi. She also established a controversial Emergency regime, which suspended civil liberties and political opposition.

input: Write a short biography of Indira Gandhi.
output: Indira Gandhi (1917-1984) was a politician, Prime Minister of India 1966-77, and chair of the political party the Indian National Congress. Born in Allahabad, Indira was raised by Mahatma Gandhi. She followed in her father's footsteps, serving as governmental minister before becoming Prime Minister in 1966. Gandhi suspended democratic norms when she declared a state of emergency in 1975, asserting executive powers. She won a landslide victory in 1977 despite the controversy, but lost in 1979 and was forced to resign. A second state of emergency followed in 1982, during which her government was accused of human rights abuses. Gandhi was assassinated by her bodyguards, reportedly because she had displeased Sikh separatists.

input: Write a short biography of Indira Gandhi.
output: Indira Gandhi (1917-1984) was the fourth Prime Minister of India, the daughter of Jawaharlal Nehru. She entered politics early, campaigned for independence in London, studied at Oxford in the mid-1930s. After her father's death in 1964, she served as Prime Minister until the mid-1970s, when she was deposed by her party. She won back power in 1980 and served until 1984, when she was assassinated by her two bodyguards, who felt she had compromised national security.

input: Write a short biography of Indira Gandhi.

Gandhi nationalized sixteen major banks and industrial companies and imposed the first state of emergency in 1975 until her resounding electoral loss in 1977.

input: Write a short biography of Jimi Hendrix.
output: Jimi Hendrix (1942-1970) was a virtuoso guitarist who established rock music as an art form. input: Write a short biography of Jimi Hendrix.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100 BC-44 BC) was a Roman politician and general and one of the most famous figures in history. He was elected consul in 59 BC, and began to push for reforms in the government. Caesar was appointed proconsul of Cisalpine Gaul (in modern Italy) in 58 BC, and conquered Brittany by 55 BC. He returned to Rome to become quaestor (treasury official), praetor (judge), and tribune (senatorial representative). A dictator and consul from 53-52 BC, Caesar led military campaigns across Europe, becoming a military hero and a leader of political reform in Rome. In 44 BC, he was appointed governor of Cisalpine Gaul again, but was assassinated by the Senate. The emperor Augustus later adopted Caesar's name along with his political policies.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100-31 BCE) was a military general and a founding father of the Roman Empire. His conquest of Gaul resulted in the creation of the Roman province in modern-day France and Belgium. He defeated an army led by the Celtic king Vercingetorix in the Gallic Wars (58-51 BCE). He was appointed dictator in 49 BCE, and crowned Emperor in 27 BCE. Caesar is remembered as a great military commander, and his name is still used for the first year of the Roman calendar.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100-44 B.C.) was a Roman general and statesman. From a poor background, he became friends with Gaius Marius, the ruler of Rome. During war with the Gauls, Caesar emerged as a great general, defeating the Germans, Egyptians, and Britons. Caesar rose to power when Sulla became consul. He later governed Gaul, Greece, and Spain. As dictator for life, Caesar expanded Rome's authority, facing opposition. His assassination triggered a 4-year civil war. He was hailed as a hero in ancient Rome and wrote a major historical work, the _Gallic Wars_.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100 BC-44 BC), served in the Roman Army and became one of the most successful commanders of his historical age. In 59 BC, he defeated a Roman general at the Battle of Alesia, ending the Gallic Wars. In 49 BC, he successfully defended the Roman Republic again an army led by Lucius Sergius Catilina. During the civil war between Pompey and Caesar, Caesar crossed the Rubicon River to take control of Rome. He ruled Rome as virtual dictator, leading troops in battles from North Africa to Greece. After winning a decisive victory at the Battle of Munda, Caesar traveled to Spain where he was assassinated by a group of senators.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100-44 BC) was a Roman general and politician. He served in leadership roles for most of his political career, ultimately becoming dictator for life. An ambitious man, Caesar sought to reform and unify Rome, but his murder led to a political crisis in the Roman Republic. After his death, Octavian was awarded a special title by the senate that cemented his rule. In addition to political conflict, Caesar is famous for military achievements. He led an invasion of Britain and an attack on Cleopatra in Alexandria. The Senate honored him with the name "Imperator" for victories in the Gallic Wars.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100-44 BCE) was a Roman general and statesman. He served as a colonel in Cisalpine Gaul, an appointment awarded by his adoptive father-in-law Caesar. A member of the First Triumvirate with Pompey and Marcus Crassus, Caesar rose to prominence in the government by defeating the Gallic tribes and becoming governor of Hispania Tarraconensis. After Crassus and Pompey's deaths in 54 BCE, Caesar led a civil war against the Senate over the constitutional future of the Republic. After assuming sole power as dictator by 45 BCE, he was assassinated by 30 senators on 15 March, leading to the civil war that became the reign of the Second Triumvirate. He is regarded as one of the greatest military leaders in history and the first Roman emperor.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100-44 BCE) was a politician and statesman whose military campaigns shaped the Roman Republic and laid the groundwork for the empire. A political opponent of his rival Pompey, Caesar allied with the Roman aristocrats, the Optimates, following his 102 CE crossing of the Rubicon. Caesar defeated Pompey in the Battle of Pharsalus in 48 BCE, becoming the head of government, chief general, and dictator of Rome for life. A series of civil wars ensued, culminating in the assassination of Caesar in 44 BCE along Pompey's side. His unheeded warning to the Roman senate of the dangers of a permanent elite caste came to pass when Brutus and Cassius seized the crown, setting off a sequence of civil wars that would eventually dissolve Rome into provincial kingdomship, as foretold in Caesar's Commentarii de Bello Gallico.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.

input: Write a short biography of Karl Marx.
output: Karl Marx (1818-1883) was a German philosopher and political economist who pioneered scientific study of history and economic development. His early work _The Communist Manifesto_ (1848) argued for a communist society in which the proletariat rises up to overthrow the capitalist elite, and he went on to write the _Das Kapital._ His writings on economics and politics have become central to Marxist thought, and he remains a controversial figure as a theorist of revolution.

input: Write a short biography of Karl Marx.

Marx's work influenced generations of socialist thinkers and revolutionaries.

input: Write a short biography of Karl Marx.
output: Karl Marx (1818-1883) was a German philosopher, literary critic, and political economist. They developed the idea of the "working class" as a unit that would seize political and economic power and bring about a classless society. For Marx and Engels, this was the communist revolution. input: Write a short biography of Karl Marx.
output: Karl Marx (1818-1883) was a German philosopher and economist. He wrote Capital: A Critique of Political Economy, a major work on class and social struggle around which socialism and Marxism were based. Concurrently, Marx co-authored (with Friedrich Engels) the influential Communist Manifesto (1848), theorizing on the working class and economic and social revolution. Marx's work emphasized the "dialectic," a type of conflict between opposing forces which eventually create synthesis and development. He also advocated for a proletariat led by communist parties to seize state power, then transition towards a society without classes or private property. Many of his theories are rejected today as outdated, but his critique of capitalism continues to play a role in modern politics, particularly that of socialist revolution and communism.

input: Write a short biography of Karl Marx.

input: Write a short biography of Karl Marx.

input: Write a short biography of Karl Marx.
