input: Write a short biography of Novak Djokovic.
output: Novak Djokovic (born 1987) is a Serbian professional tennis player. He is ranked World No.2 by the Association of Tennis Professionals and has won 18 Grand Slam singles titles, four of which are Grand Slam singles titles away from his home court, the most in tennis history. He is one of eight male players- with Nadal, Federer, Sampras, Agassi, Becker, Djokovic and Borg- to have won four or more of the Grand Slam titles. During his career, Djokovic earned close to USD 165 million from endorsements and appearance fees. In 2016, the tennis court at the ASB Tennis Centre in Auckland, in New Zealand, was renamed the 'Pete Sampras-Novak Djokovic National Tennis Centre'.

input: Write a short biography of Novak Djokovic.
output: Novak Djokovic (born 1987) is a Serbian professional tennis player who is a 15-time Grand Slam winner. He is one of the greatest players of all time, having reached 19 finals in Slams from 2011-2022. The long-time world number one won Wimbledon, the Australian Open, the US Open, four consecutive French Opens, and three consecutive Australian Opens in 2018-2022. Widely known for his charity work, Djokovic has received numerous awards for his contributions, including 2014-2015 Laureus World Sportsman of the Year.

input: Write a short biography of Novak Djokovic.
output: Novak Djokovic (born 1987) is a Serbian professional tennis player who is the No. 1 ranked player in the world. Djokovic has won fourteen Grand Slam singles titles, the second most by any player in history, trailing only Roger Federer (21 titles). In 2011, he climbed to No. 1 in the world rankings, holding that ranking for 289 consecutive weeks. He won Wimbledon four times (2011, 2014, 2015, and 2021) and the Australian Open three times (2011, 2012 and 2019).

input: Write a short biography of Novak Djokovic.
output: Novak Djokovic (born 1987) is a Serbian former world number one and one of the best tennis players of his generation. He first won the Australian Open in 2008, beating Rafael Nadal, and went on to win titles in all four Grand Slams. At 26, Djokovic won his sixth Wimbledon title, then captured his seventh major title at the 2014 US Open. He has been repeatedly named the Association of Tennis Professionals World Player of the Year. As of the summer of 2022, Djokovic has the fourth most Grand Slam singles titles in history.

input: Write a short biography of Novak Djokovic.
output: Novak Djokovic (born 1987) is a Serbian professional tennis player and one of the greatest champions in history, having won 15 Grand Slams, more than any other male player in the Open Era. After winning his first Grand Slam at the 2008 Australian Open, he rose to No. 1 in the world rankings in 2011. He won four Grand Slams in a row in 2011-12 and three more (including the French 2016 Open) in a row thereafter. He won the 2018 and 2019 Australian Open; has won at the French Open, Wimbledon, and the U.S. Open; and appeared in the semifinals or better of every Slam. At the end of 2019, he was World No. 2, behind only Rafael Nadal in the rankings.

input: Write a short biography of Novak Djokovic.
output: Novak Djokovic (born 1987) is a Serbian tennis player and three-time winner of Wimbledon. He is considered one of the greatest to ever play the sport and was a member of the "Big Four" of men's tennis. Djokovic began competing in tennis tournaments as a child, winning his first tournament at the age of eight. In 2011, he was selected as Serbia's Athlete of the Year, winning this honor six times. His success peaked in 2016, when he won three Grand Slams in the same year for the first time. He reached a career milestone in 2019 when he broke the ATP ranking record.

input: Write a short biography of Novak Djokovic.
output: Novak Djokovic (born 1987) is a former world number one professional tennis player. He is a 16-time Grand Slam singles champion, having won Wimbledon seven times and the French Open three times. He began playing tennis at five years old and played his first match at six. In 2011, Djokovic defeated Roger Federer to win the French Open, giving him his first Grand Slam title. He holds an all-time record of seven Australian Opens and has won a career total of 78 singles titles. Djokovic has long-time health issues, which caused a breakdown a few years ago, and a coaching shakeup between 2017 and 2019. Since 2020, he has had a new coach and revitalized his career, winning two Grand Slam titles in 2021.

input: Write a short biography of Novak Djokovic.
output: Novak Djokovic (born 1987) is a Serbian tennis player and the current World No. 1. He began playing tennis at age 4. After winning junior and under-14 championships in the early 2000s, he turned professional in 2003. Djokovic won the French Open and Wimbledon in 2016 to complete the "Big Four" Grand Slam titles. In 2020, he became the first man in more than 10 years to win three consecutive Grand Slams. Through 2021, Djokovic holds the single-season record for most Masters 1000 tournaments won with seven.

input: Write a short biography of Novak Djokovic.
output: Novak Djokovic (born 1987) is a Serbian tennis player. A former world number one, Djokovic has won fifteen Grand Slam titles. The youngest of three brothers, he began competing in tennis at age six, winning his first international tournament at fourteen. By 2012, he was in four consecutive Grand Slam finals. After injuries slowed his career, he regained the top spot in both rankings and titles in 2018, winning Wimbledon and the U.S. Open.

input: Write a short biography of Novak Djokovic.
output: Novak Djokovic is a Serbian professional tennis player who achieved world No. 1 rankings in 2011, 2014, 2021. He is regarded as one of the best tennis players in the world. Along with Roger Federer and Andy Murray, he was the main rival of Rafael Nadal as one of the "Big Four". He has won 15 Grand Slam titles, and is the current defending champion in both the men's singles and men's doubles tournaments at the 2021 Wimbledon championships.

input: Write a short biography of Octavia E. Butler.
output: The American writer Octavia Butler (1947-2006) wrote eight novels as well as a variety of sci-fi short stories. The books _Kindred_ (1979), _Parable of the Sower_ (1993), and _Fledgling_ (2005) were among her most popular works. Butler died at age 58 after developing breast cancer. She was a recipient of numerous awards, including a MacArthur Genius grant in 1995. A scholarly organization, the Octavia E. Butler scholarship, works to preserve her legacy.

input: Write a short biography of Octavia E. Butler.
output: Octavia E. Butler (1947-2006) was a feminist science fiction writer, known for her social commentary and exploration of race, gender, and class issues. Her many novels and short stories earned respect and influence in genre writing. She won a host of science fiction awards, including a National Book Award, a Hugo, and a Nebula. Her work has been adapted for film and television, including for her novel _Kindred_. She was inducted into the Science Fiction Hall of Fame in 2017.

input: Write a short biography of Octavia E. Butler.
output: Octavia E. Butler (1947-2006) was an African American science fiction writer best known for her critically acclaimed novel _Kindred_. She began by writing short stories for popular African American magazines, and her writings won numerous awards by the late 1970s. She was the first woman and the first African American to win the prestigious Nebula Award. She won MacArthur and Guggenheim fellowships, and served as the first President of SFWA. She died in 2005 while working on a planned sequel to _Kindred_.

input: Write a short biography of Octavia E. Butler.
output: Octavia Estelle Butler (1947-2006) was an African-American writer of science fiction and fantasy. She grew up in Pasadena, California and began writing at the age of five. While earning her university degree, she sold her first story and later received a master's in physics from California State University. Her 1980 novel _Kindred_ explored America's racial history, depicting the violence of slavery through a time-travel story. Butler won two Hugo awards, a Nebula Award, and numerous other honors. She was the first science fiction author to receive a MacArthur Fellowship.

input: Write a short biography of Octavia E. Butler.
output: Octavia E. Butler (1947-2006) was an African-American SF writer who depicted marginalized communities as heroes and explored the use of speculative fiction for social criticism. Educated at Pasadena City College and the University of California, Los Angeles, she published her first novel in 1976 and went on to win the Hugo Award in 1984. During his club career, Pelé scored 1,281 goals in 1,363 matches across various club and national tournaments. Pelé was appointed a United Nations Messenger of Peace in 1996, making him the first and only soccer player to hold the position. Pelé is widely regarded as the greatest soccer player of all time; the Brazilian government recently named a bust of the athlete in Rio de Janeiro.

input: Write a short biography of Pelé.
output: Edson Arantes do Nascimento, known as Pelé, was a Brazilian soccer player. Nicknamed O Rei or The King, he became the most decorated athlete in Olympic history with three gold medals. Pelé joined Santos at fifteen and went on to win the title four times with the club, scoring 1,282 goals in 1,363 games with the club. He debuted with the Brazilian National Team in 1957 at age 19, scoring in his first game against England. He helped Brazil win the World Cup in 1958 and 1962. Pelé announced his retirement at age 39 after the 1977 World Cup Finals, scoring 1,281 goals in 1,363 games. He remains the only soccer player to score in three World Cup Finals.

input: Write a short biography of Pink Floyd.
output: Formed in London in 1965, Pink Floyd was a British rock band. Originally consisting of students Nick Mason and the late Syd Barrett, the band's lineup was completed by Roger Waters, David Gilmour, and Richard Wright, who left in 2008. Widely regarded as one of the greatest groups of all time, Pink Floyd blended heavy psychedelic rock, progressive rock and classical music, often evoking surrealism, psychedelia and politics. Their music inspired the emergence of a new rock genre: progressive rock. After 30 years as a quartet, Pink Floyd broke up in 1995. The remaining members have continued to record and perform. The band won two Grammy awards, including best rock instrumental performance for "Shine On You Crazy Diamond."

input: Write a short biography of Pink Floyd.
output: English progressive rock band Pink Floyd was co-founded in 1965 by bassist Roger Waters, keyboardist Nick Mason and guitarist Syd Barrett. Their debut album, The Piper at the Gates of Dawn, fusing Barrett's psychedelic sound with spacey tones, helped shape the genre. Barrett left Pink Floyd in 1968 and was replaced by David Gilmour and guitarist/vocalist (and future solo artist) David Jones, who adopted the stage name 'Roger Waters'. 90 million albums sold to date make the group globally successful. Barrett and founder and remaining member Waters parted company in 2006. Mason and Gilmour are the last remaining founding members.

input: Write a short biography of Pink Floyd.
output: Pink Floyd is a legendary progressive rock band formed in 1965 in London. Throughout their career, Pink Floyd's distinct sound and performance has drawn critical acclaim. Fans consider them one of the greatest rock bands of all time. Pink Floyd's discography includes 22 albums, four singles, and multiple live albums.

input: Write a short biography of Pink Floyd.

input: Write a short biography of Pink Floyd.
output: Pink Floyd were an influential British progressive rock band. Formed in London in 1965, they released their seminal 1973 album, "The Dark Side of the Moon," topping the charts around the world. The group recorded further albums through the 1970s, including the double-disc "Animals" in 1977. The band broke up in 1983, reuniting for a one-off performance at Live Aid in 1985. Following the death of band founder Syd Barrett, Pink Floyd reunited in the mid-1990s, touring through the 2000s.

input: Write a short biography of Pink Floyd.
output: Pink Floyd were an iconic British psychedelic-rock band. Formed in Cambridge in 1965, the band's lineup included Richard Wright (keyboards), Syd Barrett (guitars), Nick Mason (drums), David Gilmour (guitars), and Roger Waters (bass and vocals). input: Write a short biography of Pink Floyd.

input: Write a short biography of Pink Floyd.
output: Pink Floyd was an internationally influential British rock band, which achieved artistic recognition with the 1967 album _The Piper at the Gates of Dawn_. The band's 1973 album _Dark Side of the Moon_ sold over 20 million copies. The 1979 live album _The Wall_ is Pink Floyd's bestselling studio album and sold over 60 million copies worldwide.

input: Write a short biography of Pink Floyd.

input: Write a short biography of Pink Floyd.

input: Write a short biography of Plato.
output: Plato (428/427 BC-348/347 BC) was a Greek philosopher, student of Socrates, and founder of the Academy, the first university in the West. Plato's work, along with his mentor Socrates', have fundamentally shaped Western philosophy, including the development of Christian theology and natural philosophy. Plato is widely considered the Founder of Western Philosophy. He wrote the Timaeus among other major works, including The Republic, The Symposium, and The Phaedo.

input: Write a short biography of Plato.
output: Plato (427/428–347/346 BCE) was a Greek philosopher and student of Socrates, whose ideas form the basis of Western philosophy. Plato believed that reason is superior to emotion and created his famous republic, called the ideal state, as a symbol of righteousness. In it, Plato defined justice, virtue, and self-control, and he proposed the role of philosopher rulers with a knowledge of morality. He founded the academy and went on to establish a famous school in Athens. Plato's philosophy influenced many figures, including Socrates, Aristotle, and the Roman stoic authors.

input: Write a short biography of Plato.
output: (circa 428 BCE-circa 348 BCE) was an Ancient Greek philosopher considered one of the fathers of Western philosophy. In the Academy he founded, Plato taught Aristotle and other influential students. Ascribed at least 20 dialogues, Plato's body of work discusses the theory and application of knowledge, politics, metaphysics, logic and ethics. A central idea in many of Plato's dialogs is an allegory from the underworld, known as the Allegory of the Cave.

input: Write a short biography of Plato.
output: Plato (c. 428/7-348/7 BCE) was a Greek philosopher, who lived during the golden age of Athens after the death of Pericles. Plato travelled across the Aegean world, finding inspiration from such Greek states as Minoan Crete and the Hellenistic city of Alexandria in Egypt. He founded the Academy in Athens, now famous for scholars like Aristotle and Plotinus. He lived under a totalitarian regime, but wrote to protect his views about philosophy from erasure. Plato is best known for his theory of Forms -- a hierarchy of pure ideas underpinning all reality.

input: Write a short biography of Plato.
output: Plato (c. 428 B.C.-348 B.C.) was a philosopher associated with the ancient Greek city of Athens and its Academy. He wrote philosophy in the form of dialogues that explored the human condition, including justice, morality, and self-knowledge. Plato challenged Homer's mythology and the values of the polis and promoted an intellectual aristocracy and communist societies in which "virtue" ruled. Although he never left Greece, his ideas heavily influenced the Romans, Christians, Muslims, and modern societies.

input: Write a short biography of Plato.
output: Plato (427-347 BCE) was a Greek philosopher and student of Socrates. He established the Academy, a school focused on philosophical pursuits in philosophy and math, and wrote the Republic and other seminal texts exploring Socrates' theories. His works are studied in both philosophy and political science. Plato advocated for a regime where moral decisions are made for the benefit of society and have a social purpose. He wrote against democracy as a method of government, arguing for an appointed aristocracy to rule.

input: Write a short biography of Plato.
output: Plato (c. 427-c. 347 BC) was a student of Socrates and one of the ancient world's most renown philosophers. Many of his written works were later lost, but his influence on medieval and modern thinkers was immense.

input: Write a short biography of Plato.
output: Plato (c. 425-348 BC) was a student of Socrates and the founder of the school of thought known as Platonism. Plato emphasized the use of logic for philosophical insight, studying dialectical philosophy and philosophy of language. He believed in the soul and created his Theory of Forms, explaining why some things were "just," "beautiful," or "good."

input: Write a short biography of Plato.
output: Plato (427-347 BCE) was a major philosopher of ancient Greece. The first Western philosopher to write in prose, Plato argued for an idealistic theory of justice and an ethical theory of self-governance. He founded the Academy in Athens, and his writings would become widely known by the ancient world. Plato's teachings still influence Western philosophy today.

input: Write a short biography of Plato.

Plato's chief philosophical works include dialogues like _Republic_ and _Seventh Letter_ , where he argued that all art and science should be ruled by reason, or "mathesis." After his death, Plato founded his own school, which later became the Academy at Athens. By the end of antiquity, his ideas influenced Muslim scholars and the Renaissance, influencing modern philosophy.

input: Write a short biography of Pythagoras.
output: Pythagoras (570-500 BCE) was an ancient Greek philosopher who founded the Pythagorean religious society in the sixth century BCE. He rejected conventional political and religious orthodoxies to develop his teachings on number theory. After his early life in Egypt, he went to western Asia Minor to study with the Milesian philosopher Anaximander. Pythagoras founded his order on the mystical notion that all objects emanated from God, with the universe created by the musical harmony of numbers. His order had major influences on later thinkers, and his mysticism contributed to Christianity.

input: Write a short biography of Pythagoras.
output: Pythagoras (582-507 BCE) was a Greek philosopher and mathematician, the founder of the Pythagorean Mystery School. As a young man, he traveled with a caravan to Egypt, Babylon, Asia Minor, and the Black Sea. He lived in Italy before settling in Croton, where he taught at the Academy. Pythagoras founded the school on the doctrine of one underlying principle which gives unity to all things. He was a noted scholar, compiling a philosophical tradition for future generations. His views on mathematics and number theory influenced generations of scholars.

input: Write a short biography of Pythagoras.
output: Pythagoras of Samos (c. 570-495 BC) was a Greek philosopher, mystic, and mathematician. Studying under Philolaus, he helped found the Pythagorean school, an influential philosophical school in ancient Greece. His teachings focused on morality and politics but his disciples' secretive practices led to his execution at the hands of the Athenian government. He is well known for discovering irrational numbers, proving the square of the hypotenuse of a right triangle is equal to the sum of the squares of the other two sides, and his Golden Rule. The Pythagorean Theorem bears his name.

input: Write a short biography of Pythagoras.

As a teenager, he began studying at the school of Lydian philosopher Thales. Pythagoras also studied astronomy and mathematics, including geometry. He founded his school in Kroton in southern Italy in 530 BC. Members of the sect took a vow of secrecy and conducted the sacred rite at sunrise and sunset. The sect's practices were banned by the Roman authorities but the Pythagoreans survived into the Middle Ages.

input: Write a short biography of Pythagoras.
output: Pythagoras (c. 570-c. 496 BC) was a Greek mathematician, philosopher and polymath. input: Write a short biography of Pythagoras.
output: Pythagoras (582–507 B.C.) was the Greek philosopher who founded the Pythagorean school in Croton, now in Italy. The school emphasized contemplation and communal living, with Pythagoras himself regarded as a prophet. The Pythagoreans developed a belief in the importance of numbers and harmonies in the universe, as well as a belief in reincarnation. Pythagoras has often been described as the father of mathematics and geometry, not only for theorems bearing his name but also for his role in the development of geometry in Greek philosophy, which reached its apogee in Euclid's Elements.

input: Write a short biography of Pythagoras.
output: Pythagoras of Samos (c. 570-c. 495 B.C.) was a Greek philosopher and mathematician. His interest in numbers was so great that he founded a cult around it. In the end, Pythagoras became interested in theology and political science, but numbers remain at the center of his philosophy and his legacy. As a philosopher, he is most famous for the theorem named after him: if a right triangle has legs that equal 5 and 12, then the hypotenuse, which is the length of the hypotenuse in a right triangle, equals 13. He also discovered that the length of a chord equals the square root of the length of the hypotenuse. Pythagoras's life was deeply influenced by his brother, Exodus, who, in addition to helping Pythagoras set up his cult, died fighting in a war.

input: Write a short biography of Pythagoras.

Later, he and his followers moved to Crotone, Italy, and he established an academy known for its musical theories and scientific studies on geometry. In 484 BCE, Pythagoras was condemned to die by his former students for committing sacrilege. He was later put to death by the Athenians, who accused him of having too much power.

input: Write a short biography of Pythagoras.
output:
Pythagoras (c. 570-490 BC) was a Greek philosopher, mathematician, and founder of the Pythagorean school. Pythagoras's teachings promoted a strict code of ethics, and included a doctrine of metempsychosis (the transmigration of souls). The Pythagorean theorem, a simple mathematical statement, is named after him. Pythagoras reportedly fled Colophon after the murder of his mentor, Pherecydes, and traveled through Egypt and Babylonia, before settling in Croton. A strict vegetarian, Pythagoras sought to live a more moral life amid the widespread practice of human sacrifice.
In 2008, the German archaeologist Manfred O. Hofer discovered a stele (or shaft with a flat top) made by Pythagoreans for "Hermodamas the Crotoniate" in Pythagoreion, Croton.

input: Write a short biography of Pythagoras.

Pythagoras believed numbers could be used to explain nature and the cosmos. He taught that music was based on harmony, or mathematical ratios, and the soul had a mathematical form. After traveling through the Mediterranean, Pythagoras returned to Croton in southern Italy, establishing a school there.

input: Write a short biography of Rachel Carson.
output: Rachel Carson (1907-1964) was an American environmentalist. She studied zoology, worked at the Bureau of Fisheries, and published books on marine biology. output: Radhakishan Damani (born 1967) is an Indian businessman, co-founder and managing director of Avenue Supermarts. Damani started his career in equity investment at 19. He founded D-Mart Supermarkets (Now DMart) in 2002 and grew it to 350 stores by 2018. The same year, Avenue Supermarts acquired DMart and went public in 2019. The company has overtaken Walmart to become India's largest supermarket chain on market cap. Today, Damani plays a leading role in Avenue Supermarts' board.

input: Write a short biography of Radhakishan Damani.
output: Radhakishan Damani (born 1963) is a South African entrepreneur and philanthropist. He founded D-Mart, a chain of supermarkets in India, in 2002. Damani sold a majority stake in D-Mart to Walmart in 2018 for $16 billion. His other businesses include stakes in ITC, Café Coffee Day and the Mumbai Indians franchise of the IPL. Damani is also a major investor in the Nifty 50 index, the leading stock market index. In 2016, Damani founded Pharande Spaces, a joint venture with DLF and Siddhi Venugopal to build affordable housing in and around Pune, India.

input: Write a short biography of Radhakishan Damani.
output: Radhakishan Damani (born 1964) is an Indian businessman and co-founder of MindTree. He is Chairman of Droom Technologies, a digital platform for auto marketing and sales. Prior to co-founding MindTree in 1999, Damani worked with Motorola and Wipro. In 2010, he sold MindTree to Engineering IT for $380 million, becoming a billionaire. Drafted for his first Indian Premier League season in 2011, Damani owns the Mumbai Indians cricket team.

input: Write a short biography of Radhakishan Damani.
output: Radhakishan Damani (born 1966) is an American-educated Indian businessman and billionaire. After graduating from the University of Pune, he joined an investment firm specializing in Indian stocks. With the help of a mentor, Damani started his own brokerage firm. Damani later started D-Mart, an Indian retail chain that he ran before selling it in 2012 for $1.4 billion. In 2015, he founded the 91Tress brand, dedicated to healthy living. Damani has served on the boards of several companies, including Fujifilm, PepsiCo, and Cognizant.

input: Write a short biography of Radhakishan Damani.
output: Radhakishan Damani (born 1972) is an Indian business magnate who founded D-Mart, a retail chain. Damani is an early A-list investor from India who has stakes in Aditya Birla Fashion & Retail and D-Mart. D-Mart is valued at $8 billion and has over 300 stores.

input: Write a short biography of Radhakishan Damani.
output: Radhakishan Damani (born 1964) is a businessman and billionaire investor who is head of D-Mart, one of the largest retailers in India. Damani started his business with a single store. Over 20 years, he turned it into a fast growing, 325 store chain that in 2020 ranked #1 in India by Brand Trust Report, with sales of over $4 billion. Damani sold most of his share of D-Mart in 2019 for $3.5 billion. He is one of India's richest people and has invested in technology, real estate, and logistics.

input: Write a short biography of Rashida Tlaib.
output: Rashida Tlaib (born 1981) is a Democratic member of Congress elected from Michigan's 13th district. She joined Congress in 2019, becoming one of the first Muslim women elected to Congress. In office, Tlaib pushed for the impeachment of President Trump.

input: Write a short biography of Rashida Tlaib.
output: Rashida Tlaib (born 1976) is the current Representative from Michigan for the Democratic Party, after winning the primary on August 7, 2018. An American of Palestinian descent, she has pushed for more Muslim women in Washington, and called for an end to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Tlaib is a longtime member of the Democratic Socialists of America and the Michigan House of Representatives, where she has worked on the auto industry rescue bill, healthcare, and minimum wage laws. She has also worked on a campaign to raise the minimum wage to 15 dollars an hour and to abolish ICE.

input: Write a short biography of Rashida Tlaib.
output: Rashida Tlaib (born 1976) is a political activist and member of the U.S. House of Representatives. At the age of 18, she co-founded the Arab American Political Action Committee. This organization organized voter registration drives and lobbied for Arab Americans' political rights. A Michigan Democrat, Tlaib sought election to public office from 2008-2014, but twice lost. In 2018, she ran for the Michigan House and won. Elected to the House as the first Muslim Congresswoman, Tlaib advocates universal healthcare and civil rights. She was impeached in 2021 on charges of harboring her son after he was found at the scene of a car crash.

input: Write a short biography of Rashida Tlaib.
output: Rashida Tlaib (born 1981) is a Democratic Representative in the U.S. House of Representatives from Michigan. She is the first Palestinian American woman to be in Congress. Rashida is a graduate of the University of Michigan School of Law, where she received her J.D. Rashida is a supporter of Israel and has received multiple awards for her work on issues pertaining to women.

input: Write a short biography of Rashida Tlaib.
output: Rashida Tlaib (born 1976) is a U.S. Representative from Michigan and one of the first Muslim women in Congress. Tlaib served on the Detroit City Council and Michigan legislature before winning election to the U.S. House in 2018. A liberal, Tlaib supported President Barack Obama's candidacy and has been credited with securing a promise from him to visit her district. Tlaib has been a vocal supporter of impeaching President Donald Trump, as well as advocated for the Boycott, Divestment, Sanctions movement.

input: Write a short biography of Rashida Tlaib.
output: Rashida Harbi Tlaib (born 1981) is an American politician and the Representative of Michigan’s 13th congressional district. A Muslim, Tlaib is the first Palestinian Muslim and the first Palestinian American woman to enter the House of Representatives. Tlaib previously served on Detroit City Council, which she was elected to in 2008. In 2018, Tlaib ran and won in Michigan’s 13th district in the congressional Democratic primary. She has championed progressive views, opposing the War on Terror and advocating for affordable healthcare, gun control, and immigration reform. She is a supporter of the Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions movement against Israel, which has been criticized as anti-Semitic in the US.

input: Write a short biography of Rashida Tlaib.
output: Rashida Tlaib (born 1976) is a US Representative for Michigan's 13th district. First elected in 2018, she is the first Muslim woman and the de facto first Palestinian American to serve in Congress. A Democrat, she has advocated for impeaching President Trump and supports Israel's right to exist. Tlaib was also president of the Detroit chapter of the NAACP. In 2020, she filed lawsuits against Trump over the Muslim Ban and his retweeting of a graphic blaming Jews for gun violence.

input: Write a short biography of Rashida Tlaib.
output: Rashida Tlaib (born 1981) is a Palestinian-American political activist and politician. She is a Democrat from Michigan who served as the first Muslim woman in the Congress. Tlaib is a critic of Israel and its occupation of Palestinian territory and supports the Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions ("BDS") movement. Tlaib advocates for an "Equitable Society," including a $16 minimum wage and universal healthcare. She defeated incumbent Democratic Representative Brenda Lawrence in 2018 and was re-elected in 2020.

input: Write a short biography of Rashida Tlaib.
output: Rashida Harbi Tlaib (born 1976) is an American politician and the U.S. Representative for Michigan's 13th congressional district. She is a member of the Democratic Party. In 2018, Tlaib became the first Palestinian-American woman elected to Congress. Since then, she has pushed for Palestinian statehood, impeaching Donald Trump and other progressive policies. In 2019, President Donald Trump blocked her travel to Israel and the Palestinian territories over her support for the boycott, divestment, and sanctions (BDS) movement.

input: Write a short biography of Rashida Tlaib.
output: Rashida Tlaib (born 1981) is a Democrat and American politician who represents Michigan in Congress. At age 18, Tlaib was the youngest woman elected to the Michigan Legislature. While in office, she was one of the 2009 Detroit 13, a group of 13 who were indicted for corruption. When she became the first Palestinian-American woman elected to Congress in 2018, Tlaib was also the first Muslim woman to serve in the House of Representatives. Her campaigns focused on criminal justice reform and Medicare for All. Tlaib announced that she would not be seeking reelection in 2020.

input: Write a short biography of Ray Charles.
output: Ray Charles (1930-2004) was an African American musician who was blind from birth. He rose to fame in the 1950s with "What'd I Say" and "Hallelujah I Love Her So." Known as the "genius behind the glasses," he recorded over 120 chart hits. Charles made his final recording in 2005 at Paste Studios in Atlanta, just weeks before his death. His influence on musicians including Stevie Wonder, Jamie Foxx, and Bruno Mars has earned him the title of "Father of Soul." During his career, the RIAA has certified 100 million record sales in the United States. He has been inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, the Apollo Theater Hall of Fame, and the Songwriters Hall of Fame.

input: Write a short biography of Ray Charles.
output: Ray Charles Robinson (1930-2004) was a blind American musician and pioneering soul singer-songwriter. Born into poverty in Georgia, he started singing gospel music as a child. After a recording session led to a contract with Atlantic, Charles signed with Ahmet Ertegun. His 1959 hit "What'd I Say" kick started the genre of soul music. He went on to work with Otis Redding and Sam Cooke, developing a blended style influenced by jazz and gospel. Charles released a string of R&B hits, including "Georgia on My Mind" and "Hit the Road Jack." His 1999 biopic, "Ray," was nominated for eight Academy Awards.

input: Write a short biography of Ray Charles.
output: Ray Charles (1930-2004) was a pioneering American singer-songwriter and pianist. One of the originators of soul, his music crossed genres and cultures. A quadruple inductee to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, Charles sold over 120 million records over the course of his career. He collaborated with Duke Ellington, Muddy Waters, and other legends. In 2015 he was posthumously awarded the Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award.

input: Write a short biography of Ray Charles.
output: Ray Charles (1930-2004) was an American soul and R&B singer, songwriter and pianist. Charles' music incorporated various genres such as jazz and blues with gospel, country, folk and rock and roll. A master of the Hammond organ, his hits include "Hit the Road Jack," "I've Got a Woman" and a song about segregation, "I Can't Stop Loving You." A respected vocalist and songwriter, Charles was also blind. He was inducted into the rock and roll hall of fame and received an honorary doctorate of music from Harvard.

input: Write a short biography of Ray Charles.
output: Ray Charles (1930-2004) was a blues singer, guitarist, songwriter and pianist. Beginning with the genre's gritty sounds, he refined his musical and compositional style to incorporate elements of big band jazz, R&B and orchestral music. His style grew into soul and funk, combining the best of genres into a personal and original repertoire that influenced generations of musicians. He became a multi-instrumentalist, but his trademark sound was always his distinctive voice. A long musical career made him a national icon; he has been inducted into 13 different halls of fame.

input: Write a short biography of Ray Charles.
output: Ray Charles Robinson (1930-2004) was a pioneer of Rhythm & Blues and soul music. He overcame physical disability to become a celebrated performer, and is considered to be "the bridge between rhythm and blues and soul". In his long career, which began in the 1940s and continued until his death, Charles recorded more than 500 songs and won 11 Grammy awards. He was the first R&B artist to host his own variety show, The Ray Charles Show, in the early 1960s. Charles began his career as a studio musician, but is best known for the innovations he made as a live performer. He was also famous as the "Genius behind the Piano."

input: Write a short biography of Ray Charles.
output: Ray Charles Robinson (1930-2004) was a blind African-American singer, songwriter, and pianist who was a pioneer of soul music and R&B. He performed with a band of his own creation and toured the country. His hit 1959 single "What'd I Say" went to number 1 on the R&B charts, and its 1961 single "Hit the Road Jack" achieved massive popularity. In 1963, he released "I Can't Stop Loving You," which earned him his first Grammy Award.

input: Write a short biography of Ray Charles.
output: Ray Charles (1930-2004) was a US pianist and singer, a pioneer of soul music. A music prodigy, he gained fame with Atlantic Records but launched a successful solo career from the 1950s. The "father of soul," Charles fused rhythm and blues, gospel, jazz, and country music into a distinctive sound. He wrote many hit songs, including "Unchain My Heart" and "Georgia on My Mind." Charles won eighteen Grammy Awards and was among the first musicians inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.

input: Write a short biography of Ray Charles.
output: Ray Charles (1930-2004) was a leading American soul singer and one of the most influential musicians of the 1950s and '60s. He first performed as "Ray Charles Robinson," and later shortened his name to simply "Ray Charles." He began playing music at 4 and was blinded at age 7. He began performing professionally in 1945 and signed with Atlantic Records in 1952. His hits included "What'd I Say," "Unchain My Heart" and "Hit the Road Jack." Charles pioneered the blending of gospel with R&B and jazz, and helped popularize the electric organ and the Hammond B-3. He inspired generations of soul singers.

input: Write a short biography of Ray Charles.
output: Ray Charles Robinson (1930-2004) was an American singer, musician, and composer. An influential figure in blues, country, R&B, and jazz, he is often seen as the father of soul music. Discovered by Atlantic Records' Ahmet Ertegun, "Sweet Georgia Brown" was his first hit single in 1952 and was followed by "I Got a Woman" in 1953. His "Hit the Road Jack" became a rhythm and blues standard.

input: Write a short biography of Rick Warren.
output: Rick Warren (born 1954) is a popular author and pastor in the United States. He is founder and senior pastor of Saddleback Church in California which has become one of the most attended churches in America. Warren authored the book The Purpose Driven Life, which sold more than 30 million copies and was translated into 50 languages. He authored numerous other bestselling books on topics like the Holy Spirit, parenting, marriage and the Bible. Warren became a national figure during the Obama presidency.

input: Write a short biography of Rick Warren.
output: Rick Warren (1954–2022) was one of the world's most prominent evangelical pastors. He founded the influential Saddleback Church and wrote the spiritual guide book, The Purpose Driven Life. Following a public campaign for same-sex marriage in 2012, Warren distanced himself from evangelical leaders. The church also faced financial challenges after some members left the congregation. Held in high esteem by many people of faith, he criticized Trump over his divisive rhetoric. He was diagnosed with cancer in 2013, his son reported in December 2021, but never spoke about it publicly.

input: Write a short biography of Rick Warren.
output: Rick Warren (born 1954) is an American pastor and author who founded Saddleback Church in the Los Angeles area. An influential preacher, he is known for his focus on evangelism and the "purpose-driven life." His bestselling book, The Purpose-Driven Life, promoted practical spiritual principles. Warren has been criticized by liberals who accuse him of promoting reactionary doctrine.

input: Write a short biography of Rick Warren.
output: Rick Warren (born 1954) is the pastor of Saddleback Church, a megachurch outside Los Angeles. Raised in seminary-going families, he received his degree in theology from California Baptist College. Warren founded the nondenominational Saddleback Church, with a congregation of over 20,000. He also co-authored the New York Times bestselling book The Purpose Driven Life which, with over 45 million copies sold, is the 13th best-selling book of all time. A supporter of Israel, Warren condemned homosexuality and the practice of Islam in the book, which had a significant influence on the religious right. Warren was a chaplain at National Prayer Breakfast in 2015 and spoke at the funeral of former President George H.W. Bush in 2018.

input: Write a short biography of Rick Warren.
output: Rick Warren (born 1954) is a pastor and best-selling author, founding pastor of Saddleback Church and founder of Saddleback Community Church. He has authored eight widely-read books, including The Purpose Driven Life, and served on President Obama's religious advisory council. Born to Baptist parents in California, he helped found the nonprofit Pastors & Leadership conferences in the 1990s and started Saddleback Church. He has also served as director of Global AIDS at UNAIDS.

input: Write a short biography of Rick Warren.
output: Rick Warren (born 1954) is the senior pastor at Saddleback Church and is known for his broad, cross-denominational influence. Warren began his ministry at Saddleback in 1980. The largest church in Orange County, California, Saddleback's congregation has grown from 200 to nearly 22,000 under Warren's leadership. He has also authored several books on living the "Purpose-Driven Life," including The Purpose Driven Life" and The Purpose-Driven Church. Warren is a political conservative, criticizing some progressive policies as a "moral failure."

input: Write a short biography of Rick Warren.
output: Rick Warren (born 1954) is the founder of Saddleback Church. Warren co-authored the 2004 book The Purpose Driven Life, which has sold more than 30 million copies. Warren has spoken at the Congressional Prayer Breakfast, the White House, and at events hosted by the UK government. Warren's other books include The Purpose Driven Church. In 2018, Warren's son committed suicide, leading to a major review of pastoral care in churches.

input: Write a short biography of Rick Warren.
output: Rick Warren (born 1954) is an American pastor and author. He founded Saddleback Church in Lake Forest, California, a congregation with over 20,000 members. Warren authored The Purpose-Driven Life, which sold 20 million copies. He founded the nondenominational evangelical global megachurch, Saddleback Church. Warren founded the Saddleback Community Church in Southern California in 1980; with over 24,000 members, it is one of the largest congregations in the United States. Warren established the P.E.A.C.E. Plan; his Saddleback Church and other groups have donated over $150 million to help HIV/AIDS patients, build wells, provide food, and help with refugee issues. He is involved with the U.S. branch of the Lausanne Committee for World Evangelism.

input: Write a short biography of Rick Warren.
output: Rick Warren (born 1954) is the founder and senior pastor of California megachurch Saddleback Church. Warren pioneered the use of church-growth techniques at Saddleback, serving as the model for "seeker-friendly" churches. He has written multiple books on Christian-living and worldwide outreach. His best-known book is The Purpose Driven Life, which sold more than 50 million copies. He founded the Saddleback Global Health Outreach to fight disease and the Day by Day initiative to reduce suicide. Warren opposes same-sex marriage, abortion, and stem cell research.

input: Write a short biography of Rick Warren.
output: Rick Warren (born 1954) is a pastor and author in California. He founded Saddleback Church in 1980 and helped launch the evangelical megachurch movement. He has written several Christian bestsellers, including The Purpose Driven Life, and started the nonprofit charity group Saddleback Church outreach. He and his wife Kay have three children and nine grandchildren. In 2010, Warren was listed as the fifth most influential evangelical in America, and by the end of the decade he considered his life's biggest accomplishment being a pastor to three congregations. After the Parkland shooting, Warren drew criticism from some faith leaders for his responses.

input: Write a short biography of Rigoberta Menchú.
output: Rigoberta Menchú (1959-2020) was a Nobel Peace Prize laureate who promoted indigenous rights in Guatemala and across the Americas. Her parents were killed during the Guatemalan civil war. As a teenager, Menchú joined the socialist Guatemalan Army of National Liberation and served as a guerilla. She became internationally famous after publishing her memoir in 1983, earning a Nobel Peace Prize in 1992. Menchú was active in human rights until her death in 2020. She has been denounced as a communist and accused of making up her family tragedy, disputes which she reiterated in her work and political activism.

input: Write a short biography of Rigoberta Menchú.
output: Rigoberta Menchú (born 1959) is a Guatemalan indigenous environmentalist and former political refugee. She fled the country as a student during the Guatemalan Civil War, when leftist revolutionaries and the army fought for control. After immigrating to Mexico and eventually to the U.S., she was awarded the 1992 Nobel Peace Prize for her work advocating for indigenous peoples rights. Menchú published her acclaimed autobiography, _I, Rigoberta Menchú: An Indian Woman in Guatemala,_ in 1983. She has also published another autobiography, _When I Loved My Home._ She has been a UN Goodwill Ambassador since 2001. Her memoirs, activism, and poetry have been recognized in different awards.

input: Write a short biography of Rigoberta Menchú.
output: Rigoberta Menchú (born 1959) is a Guatemalan indigenous activist. She became a political voice after the murder of her parents in 1981. She was subsequently ostracized from her community for working with the government and in 1990 became the first indigenous woman to receive the Nobel Peace Prize. Menchú has fought for the rights of indigenous people in Guatemala and internationally. A controversial book, I, Rigoberta Menchú claimed to have drawn from her memories but later came under fire for invented or exaggerated elements.

input: Write a short biography of Rigoberta Menchú.
output: Rigoberta Menchú Tum (born 1959) is an indigenous Guatemalan and Nobel laureate, known for her role as a political activist for indigenous political and human rights. A student of her own people's Mayan language while working as a camp nurse, she took an active role in Guatemala's 1996 peace accords. Menchú was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1992 for her activities.

input: Write a short biography of Rigoberta Menchú.
output: Rigoberta Menchú, now 62, is a Nobel Peace laureate and prominent activist. As a teenager, she joined the Guatemalan insurgency against the government in the 1960s. The daughter of an indigenous Quiché activist, she left to study in Switzerland for most of the 1980s before moving to Geneva in 1983. In 1992, she published her first memoir, titled I, Rigoberta Menchú, which earned her the 1992 Nobel Peace Prize. Today, she continues to push for reparation for the Guatemalan genocide.

input: Write a short biography of Rigoberta Menchú.
output: Rigoberta Menchú (born 1959) is a Guatemalan indigenous rights activist and winner of the 1992 Nobel Peace Prize. Her experience as a survivor of the Guatemalan Civil War led to her founding of the human rights organization, Rigoberta Menchú Tum Foundation with her brother, a former UN consultant. The Nobel Peace prize committee honored Menchú "for her work for social justice and ethno-cultural reconciliation based on respect for the rights of indigenous peoples."

input: Write a short biography of Rigoberta Menchú.
output: Rigoberta Menchú (born 1959) is a Guatemalan human rights activist. In 1983, she testified before the United Nations Commission on Human Rights about the violence her family endured under the regime of Efraín Ríos Montt. Menchú was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1992 for speaking out about government-sponsored genocide in Guatemala. She went on to work with indigenous organizations across Latin America and became a prominent supporter of President Jimmy Carter's anti-discrimination initiatives. Many Guatemalans still consider her a national hero, while others think her story is one-sided and politically motivated.

input: Write a short biography of Rigoberta Menchú.
output: Rigoberta Menchú Tum (born 1959) is a Guatemalan lawyer, activist, and Nobel Peace Prize laureate. She survived the civil war in Guatemala as the daughter of two teachers who were arrested and later killed. Rigoberta became active in anti-government demonstrations, which ended with her arrest in 1981. The Guatemalan military tortured her, killing one of her uncles. She was eventually released, fleeing into exile for Mexico. Rigoberta became a key leader of the Mayan-Indigenous rights movement, and her testimony was vital to a UN truth commission which called for justice for the indigenous population.

input: Write a short biography of Rigoberta Menchú.
output: Rigoberta Menchú (1959-2020) was a leader of the Guatemalan indigenous movement who received the Nobel Peace Prize in 1992. She was 15-years-old when a military massacre of her family led her to write a personal account called "I, Rigoberta Menchú." A Guatemalan-Salvadoran lawyer who helped her work get published then introduced her to the Nobel committee. Menchú wrote her account in Spanish and later in Quiche, the indigenous Mayan language of K’iche' people. It was later translated into 30 languages.

input: Write a short biography of Rigoberta Menchú.
output: Rigoberta Menchú (1959- ) is a Nobel Peace Prize winner and activist for indigenous rights. Menchú was a student when a massacre killed her father and many of her relatives. The army also raped her and the neighboring family's daughter. The two teenagers united and eventually married. Menchú then traveled to Geneva to receive human rights training, becoming a leading activist for indigenous rights. She was appointed to Guatemala's Foreign Ministry by President Alvaro Colom and campaigned for a United Nations probe of indigenous deaths. She won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1992 but is considered a controversial figure. She was accused of plagiarism in her autobiography and has been the subject of multiple lawsuits. Menchú and several family members were later killed in a fire.

input: Write a short biography of Rihanna.
output: Robyn Rihanna Fenty (born 1988), known by her stage name Rihanna or RiRi, is a Barbadian singer and actress. She was discovered at age 16 by the producer Evan Rogers, and later signed with Def Jam, releasing her debut "Music of the Sun" in 2005. A second album, "A Girl Like Me," followed. Rihanna's third album, "Good Girl Gone Bad," included the singles "Umbrella" and "Disturbia," which led to a Grammy Award for Album of the Year. Rihanna has starred in several films, including "Valerian" (2017) and "Guava Island" (2019). She is currently pursuing a career in fashion, working with designers such as Chanel and Manolo Blahnik.

input: Write a short biography of Rihanna.
output: Robyn Rihanna Fenty (born 1988) is a Barbadian pop singer and businesswoman. She gained prominence in 2005 with the album _Music, which was nominated for eight Grammy Awards and two BRIT awards. Rihanna was one of the world's top music artists of the 2000s. She has worked with Drake, Eminem, and JAY-Z, and released a number of successful albums, including _Anti_, _Loud_, and _Unapologetic_. Rihanna is considered a music icon, and one of the best-selling artists ever. She is the wealthiest female musician in the world (although Beyoncé is second and Madonna is fourth, according to _Forbes_).

input: Write a short biography of Rihanna.
output: Rihanna (born Robyn Fenty, 1988) is a Bajan recording artist, actress, and fashion designer. At 16, she auditioned for a recording contract, but was denied. She released her debut album, Music of the Sun, in 2005. Four more albums followed, including Good Girl Gone Bad (2007), and Loud (2010). Rihanna began acting in 2009. Her films include Battleship and Ocean's Eight. She won three Grammy Awards, two American Music Awards, and the 2018 MTV Video Music Award for Video of the Year. She has donated to charities, including UNICEF and the Clara Lionel Foundation.

input: Write a short biography of Rihanna.
output: Rihanna (born 1988) is a Bajan singer and businesswoman. Her debut album, 2006's "Music of the Sun" reached #3 in the UK. Since then, she has produced multiple hit singles including "Umbrella," "Don't Stop the Music," "We Found Love," and "Work." Rihanna has won eight Grammys and released best-selling albums including "Anti," "R8," and "Unapologetic." She founded the lifestyle brand Fenty, named in honor of her grandmother, in 2017. Rihanna has also become an iconic fashion influencer with her Fenty Beauty makeup line.

input: Write a short biography of Rihanna.
output: Rihanna (born 1988) is a singer, songwriter and actress. She was discovered by record producer Evan Rogers while in the Caribbean. Her debut single "Pon de Replay" topped the Billboard charts and sparked a string of hits. Her fourth album Good Girl Gone Bad (2007) featured hit singles "Umbrella" and " Disturbia" and landed her her first Grammy. After taking time off from her music career to focus on acting, she returned in 2012 with Unapologetic and in 2016 released her eighth album Anti. In 2015, Time magazine named Rihanna one of the 100 Most Influential People in the World.

input: Write a short biography of Rihanna.
output: Robyn Rihanna Fenty, better known as Rihanna, (born 1988) is a Barbadian superstar singer-songwriter and supermodel. In 2017, Forbes named Rihanna the world's richest solo musician ($600 million). Her music includes club anthems ("Umbrella"), ballads (the 2016 single "Needed Me"), as well as her own reggae and calypso fusions. Her music videos are often controversial, with Rihanna herself often a centerpiece. Known for her fashion sense and makeup empire, Rihanna supports charities and causes including those promoting diversity, women's reproductive rights, and education, among others. She has received awards including eight Grammy's, eight American Music Awards, and the 2016 CFDA Fashion Icon Award.

input: Write a short biography of Rihanna.
output: Rihanna (born 1988) is a Grammy award-winning singer-songwriter, born in Saint Michael Parish, Barbados. She began her career at aged 16 on the American reality television series _Star Search._ She signed with Def Jam Recordings in 2005. Her debut single _Music of the Sun_ debuted at #2 on the _Billboard_ chart. She topped the _Billboard_ Hot 100 in 2016 with _Work._ Rihanna won 13 Grammy awards, including the top award Best Album. Besides being a major pop star, she is also an actress, filming the movies _Battleship_ and _Blade_ _Runner_. Rihanna has become one of the world's highest-paid celebrities, earning $570 million between 2017-2020. Her music, style and charity work, including the Fenty Foundation and Clara Lionel Foundation, have inspired millions of her fans. She has received numerous humanitarian honors, including the Harvard Humanitarian of the Year Award.

input: Write a short biography of Rihanna.
output: Rihanna (born Robyn Rihanna Fenty, 1988) is a Barbados-born, American singer, songwriter, actress, and entrepreneur. Rihanna first rose to fame in 2005 with her debut album "Music of the Sun" and her second album, "A Girl Like Me," was a commercial success. With her 2012 single "Diamonds," Rihanna became the most played female artist on United States radio. In 2020, she released her ninth studio album "Just One of the Guys" and 2021's "The Crown." Rihanna has also starred in numerous films and television series including "Ocean's Eleven" and "Bates Motel."

input: Write a short biography of Rihanna.
output: Rihanna (born 1988) is a Barbadian singer, songwriter, and actress. Since her debut in 2005, she has sold more than 250 million records, earned eight Grammy awards, and starred in major Hollywood films. She released her first studio album, Music of the Sun, at age 17. Her following three albums, A Girl like Me, Good Girl Gone Bad, and Rated R, were all among the top 15 albums sold worldwide and the top 10 in the United States. Rihanna's 2016 album, Anti, was her most popular to date, reaching number three in the United States and the top-selling album of the year. While a student in Barbados, she participated in many school dramas and was encouraged to move to the United States after one of those productions. Her singles include "Umbrella," "We Found Love," and "Work." She has won more than 100 awards including two MTV Movie Awards, seven American Music Awards, and eight Grammy Awards.

input: Write a short biography of Rihanna.
output: Rihanna (born 1988) is a singer, songwriter and businesswoman. Discovered by music producer Evan Rogers at a Barbados talent contest, she began recording at 16. Rihanna's 2005 debut album, Music of the Sun, reached No. 3 on the Billboard charts and included top hits "SOS", "Unfaithful", and "Pon De Replay." Her 2006 followup album, A Girl Like Me, broke the top 10. Rihanna released her first Grammy-nominated album in 2007, Good Girl Gone Bad, featuring singles "Umbrella" and "Don't Stop the Music." In 2015, her eighth album Anti entered the Billboard Top 5. Forbes magazine ranked Rihanna the third highest earning female musician for 2017. Off-stage, Rihanna has won acclaim for her philanthropy and advocacy. She has been honored by PETA for her animal rights work, and founded the Clara Lionel Foundation, which works to improve health and education in the Carib

input: Write a short biography of Steven Pinker.
output: Steven Pinker (born 1954) is a Canadian-American linguist and evolutionary psychologist. He is known for his work on language, cognitive science, and psychology. Pinker is a proponent of the "Blank Slate Theory," which suggests that human personality and behavior is largely the product of genetics and environment, not nature versus nurture. He was chairman of the Harvard College Board of Fellows and director of the Good Judgment Project, which aims to improve predictions of global events. He has criticized the left for what he sees as abandoning reason and science.

input: Write a short biography of Susan B. Anthony.
output: Susan Brownell Anthony (1820-1906) was one of the main leaders in the women's suffrage movement. As a child, she moved from rural New York to Rochester, New York, where she worked as a seamstress and was encouraged to educate herself. She became an abolitionist and anti-slavery lecturer in 1849, joining women's rights activist Elizabeth Cady Stanton in 1851. She was arrested in 1872 for paying taxes despite being denied the right to vote. In 1873, Anthony and Stanton organized the first women's conference dedicated solely to the woman's rights. Anthony was arrested again in 1874. In 1878, the Supreme Court overturned the conviction of Anthony. The Anthony Amendment to the U.S. Constitution—granting women the right to vote—was ratified in 1920.

input: Write a short biography of Ta-Nehisi Coates.

input: Write a short biography of Ta-Nehisi Coates.

input: Write a short biography of Ta-Nehisi Coates.

input: Write a short biography of The Beatles.

input: Write a short biography of The Beatles.

input: Write a short biography of The Beatles.

input: Write a short biography of The Beatles.

input: Write a short biography of The Beatles.

input: Write a short biography of The Beatles.

input: Write a short biography of Thích Nhất Hạnh.

Nhất Hạnh is a longtime pacifist and environmentalist who founded the Vietnamese nonviolent movement. Nhất Hạnh has also taught mindfulness in prisons and schools, including the University of Virginia and Harvard University.

input: Write a short biography of Thích Nhất Hạnh.

input: Write a short biography of Thích Nhất Hạnh.

He taught religion at various Parisian universities in the 1960s, but left academia in 1968 to found the Plum Village Monastery in France. His Zen and Vipassana-inflected teachings of mindfulness and non-attachment have been adapted in the West for corporations, hospitals, schools and prisons.

input: Write a short biography of Thích Nhất Hạnh.

input: Write a short biography of Thích Nhất Hạnh.

input: Write a short biography of Thích Nhất Hạnh.

input: Write a short biography of Thích Nhất Hạnh.

input: Write a short biography of Tu Youyou.

input: Write a short biography of Tu Youyou.

input: Write a short biography of Tu Youyou.

input: Write a short biography of Tu Youyou.

input: Write a short biography of Tu Youyou.

input: Write a short biography of Tu Youyou.

input: Write a short biography of Tu Youyou.

input: Write a short biography of Tu Youyou.

input: Write a short biography of Tu Youyou.

input: Write a short biography of U2.

They have won over 20 Grammys and released 15 studio albums over the course of more than forty years. U2's political and social activism have helped them win the Nobel Peace Prize in 2015.

input: Write a short biography of U2.

input: Write a short biography of U2.

input: Write a short biography of Uday Kotak.

input: Write a short biography of Uday Kotak.

input: Write a short biography of Uday Kotak.

input: Write a short biography of Usain Bolt.
output: Usain Bolt (born 1986) is a Jamaican sprinter and winner of the 2008, 2012, and 2016 Olympic gold medals in the men's 100 and 200 meter races. Bolt won the first two of these races in Athens and Beijing, while the 2016 gold was a two-man race held in Rio de Janeiro. He's the third-fastest sprinter in history, behind fellow Jamaicans Merlene Ottey and Donald Quarrie, and as of November 2018, the only man to record 9.58 seconds or faster in the 100 meters. After retiring from sports in 2017, Bolt transitioned into a television personality role.

input: Write a short biography of Usain Bolt.
output: Usain St. Leo Bolt (born 1986) is a Jamaican sprint athlete widely considered the world's fastest man. In 2008 he became the first athlete to win gold medals in the 100m, 200m, and 4x100m relay at each of the international competitions. Bolt won three medals in both the 100m and 200m in 2012 despite suffering from a foot injury. In the London 2012 Games, Bolt set new world records in both races while running in the heats, the first man to achieve this feat. She was a founding member of the Bloomsbury group of writers and artists, publishing three novels and two volumes of short stories with the Hogarth Press. Woolf lived in a houseboat on the Thames for the last years of her life. She committed suicide in 1941.

input: Write a short biography of Virginia Woolf.
output: Virginia Woolf (1882-1941) was a groundbreaking British novelist and essayist who was a leading figure in modernist literature. Her works examine the roles of women in society, and she was a strong critic of male dominance. Woolf studied at Cambridge University before marrying author and journalist Leonard Woolf and becoming a leading member of the Bloomsbury group. Her novels, The Waves, Mrs. Dalloway, and To the Lighthouse are widely considered major works of modernism. Though Woolf struggled with mental health issues, she lived until 1941, dying by suicide.

input: Write a short biography of Virginia Woolf.
output: Virginia Woolf (1882-1941) was an English novelist who was influential in modernist literature. In her early novels, she focused on the details of daily life and the internal lives of the characters, using stream of consciousness to express the characters' thoughts. Her later works explored feminist themes, unconventional characters, and the impact of war on the self. In 1922, she founded the Hogarth Press with her partner Leonard Woolf. Her works of fiction include _Mrs. Dalloway_ (1925); _To the Lighthouse_ (1927); _The Waves_ (1931); _Jacob's Room_ (1922); _A Room of One's Own_ (1929); _Orlando_ (1928); and _The Years_ (1937).

input: Write a short biography of Virginia Woolf.
output: Virginia Woolf (1882-1941) was a British novelist and essayist and a founding member of the modernist movement. She is among the most widely read and influential writers of the twentieth-century. Woolf wrote many important novels, including Mrs. Dalloway (1925), To the Lighthouse (1927), and Orlando (1928). Her essays are regarded as masterpieces of feminist criticism, including A Room of One's Own (1929), titled after a line from Shakespeare's Hamlet. Born to a prominent Victorian literary family, she suffered from bipolar disorder and completed suicide in 1941.

input: Write a short biography of Virginia Woolf.
output: Virginia Woolf (1882-1941) was a British modernist novelist and essayist. She published nearly 30 books, including _Mrs. Dalloway (_1925) and _A Room of One's Own_, a 1929 nonfiction work advocating for a woman-centric educational system. An important member of the Bloomsbury Group and one of the most important writers in English-language literature, she was one of the most respected literary lights in modernism. She often wrote while experiencing severe bouts of mental illness, and committed suicide in 1941.

input: Write a short biography of Virginia Woolf.

input: Write a short biography of Virginia Woolf.

input: Write a short biography of Virginia Woolf.
output: Virginia Woolf (1882-1941) was an English novelist whose works explored the hidden forces that controlled the lives of women in traditional society. One of the founders of modern literature, she was a prolific author and was highly influential in the literary and artistic movements of her time. Her most famous works include To the Lighthouse, Mrs. Dalloway, and Jacob's Room. Though born into a distinguished and wealthy family, her life was marked by tragedy and mental illness. input: Write a short biography of Virginia Woolf.
output: Virginia Woolf (1882-1941) was an influential British writer of novels, essays, and short stories. As a feminist, her works also advocated for the emancipation of women. Woolf's early works include the experimental novel “The Voyage Out”, a novel of urban life “Jacob's Room”, and one of the first psychological studies of modern life, “Mrs. Dalloway.” Between 1925 and 1941, Woolf produced the best-known novels of the modernist period in English, including “To the Lighthouse,” “Mrs. Dalloway,” “Orlando,” "The Waves" and "The Years." Woolf worked with her lover, the writer Vita Sackville-West, and in 1931 the two married. After Sackville-West's death, Woolf committed suicide in 1941. Her novels were widely praised by critics and influenced literary movements.

input: Write a short biography of Vladimir Lenin.
output: Vladimir Lenin (1870-1924) was a Russian communist revolutionary and founder of the Soviet Union. A talented student, Lenin studied law in Kazan. In 1895, he went to Paris to study but was expelled from France after an arrest for calling for revolution. Later, Lenin settled in St. Petersburg, where he organized the Bolsheviks. During World War I, Lenin campaigned against the Czarist regime and called for a socialist revolution. In 1917, he led a Bolshevik seizure of power that established the Soviet Union. Lenin ruled as chairman of the Council of People's Commissars until his death. His followers built an authoritarian state modeled on the one Marx and Engels called for in the Communist Manifesto.

input: Write a short biography of Vladimir Lenin.
output: Vladimir Ilyich Ulyanov (1870-1924) was the leader of the Bolshevik Party and Soviet Russia. Raised by a schoolteacher, Ulyanov worked as a printer, bookbinder, and journalist in Russia and Western Europe before graduating from the University of Saint Petersburg. He became a socialist and moved to Switzerland in 1895, publishing several books on Marxism. Returning to Russia in 1900, he helped publish _Pravda_ and became involved in violent revolutionary activity. As Lenin, he organized the 1917 October Revolution that brought the Bolsheviks to power in Russia. In 1918, he formed the USSR, which grew to cover much of Europe and Asia. Lenin introduced Communist policies throughout the Soviet Union and oversaw the rise of Joseph Stalin. He suffered a stroke in 1923 and died in 1924.

input: Write a short biography of Vladimir Lenin.
output: Vladimir Ilyich Ulyanov (1870-1924) was a Russian revolutionary and Soviet leader. A trained lawyer, Lenin worked as a journalist. After being exiled from Russia, he established a new communist party to lead the Russian Revolution. As leader of the Bolsheviks, Lenin became the head of the Soviet Union and implemented Marxist policies. In 1922, he developed the idea of "scientific socialism" (Leninism) in which the vanguard party leads the state. Lenin developed authoritarian leadership tactics for building socialism, establishing one-party rule and an economic command economy. Though praised by some for his Marxism, others criticized his harsh policies during the Russian Civil War and the Great Famine.

Lenin led the October 1917 Bolshevik Revolution, which overthrew the provisional government and eventually founded the Soviet Union. A committed socialist, Lenin implemented radical policies such as economic centralization and state control of industry. His government was responsible for mass repression and the purges of the 1930s. Lenin was succeeded as General Secretary by Josef Stalin.

input: Write a short biography of Vladimir Lenin.
output: Vladimir Lenin (1870-1924) was a Russian communist revolutionary and leader of the Soviet Union. After graduating in law, he became a revolutionary and was exiled to Siberia. Returning to St. Petersburg, he launched Pravda, the Soviet Party newspaper. A key member of the Bolshevik party, he helped lead the Russian Revolution and then became the country's first communist ruler. After a disastrous civil war, the Bolsheviks defeated rival parties and Lenin established the Soviet Union. A controversial figure, he instituted communist reforms which eventually led to economic collapse and the Cold War. He died after a long illness in 1924.

input: Write a short biography of Wangari Maathai.
output: Wangari Maathai (1940-2011) was a Kenyan environmental and political activist. She earned a Ph.D. in biology in U.S. and began working for the UN Development Program. In 1977, Maathai founded the Green Belt Movement. For the next 40 years, she trained an army of female "tree-planters" who mobilized to conserve Kenyan waterways, planted over 50 million trees and helped save several endangered species. She won the Nobel Prize for Peace in 2004 and was elected to the Kenyan Parliament, where she spoke out against the Kenyan government.

input: Write a short biography of Wangari Maathai.
output: Wangari Maathai (1940-2011) was a plant scientist and environmental activist from Kenya. She studied in Kenya, Tanzania, and the United States. She was a candidate for the Kenyan presidency in 2002 and won the Nobel Peace Prize in 2004. She was also awarded the United Nations Environment Programme's highest honor in 2009.

input: Write a short biography of Wangari Maathai.
output: Wangari Maathai (1940-2011) was a Kenyan biologist and Nobel Peace Prize laureate. She founded Green Belt Movement, a grassroots environmental activism group, in 1977--a project she also used to support political and democratic protest. Maathai was made Nobel Peace laureate in 2004, becoming the first African woman and first environmental activist to receive the award. In 2005, she published The Challenge for Africa, which argues that economic development causes environmental degradation. Maathai was murdered in 2011 by unknown assailants.

input: Write a short biography of Wangari Maathai.
output: Wangari Maathai (1940-2011) was a human rights activist and environmentalist from Kenya. Known as "Mama Wangari," she was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 2004 and the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2006. She died of cancer in 2011, aged 71.

input: Write a short biography of Wangari Maathai.

input: Write a short biography of Wangari Maathai.
output: Wangari Maathai (1940-2011) was a Kenyan environmentalist and winner of the 2004 Nobel Peace Prize. input: Write a short biography of Wangari Maathai.

input: Write a short biography of Whitney Houston.
output: The late New Jersey-born singer is considered one of the greatest pop singers of all time. Houston emerged in the 1980s with chart-topping hits like "How Will I Know" and “Saving All My Love." After overdosing on cocaine in 2002, “The Voice” went clean and staged a huge comeback two years later with “I Will Always Love You” and 2003's My Love Is Your Love." The National Association of Recording Arts and Science inducted Whitney into the Grammy Hall of Fame in 2012, and her star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame was rededicated following her death.

input: Write a short biography of Whitney Houston.
output: Whitney Houston (1963-2012) was an American singer who dominated the R&B charts and the adult contemporary pop charts during the 1980s and early 1990s and was a crossover music success during the 1990s. She released several Grammy-winning albums, but her success was tarnished by personal issues and drug addiction. Houston died suddenly in 2012 of accidental drowning and heart disease, a death ruled an "accidental drowning due to the effects of atherosclerotic heart disease and cocaine use." She is considered one of the most successful recording artists of all time.

input: Write a short biography of Whitney Houston.
output: Whitney Houston (1963-2012) was a Grammy-award-winning singer and actress. Born into a family of musicians, she released her eponymous debut album in 1985. The singer rose to fame with her 1987 hit "How Will I Know," and enjoyed a string of R&B, pop and soul hit albums in the 1980s and 90s. In 1992 she starred in "The Bodyguard" opposite Kevin Costner and in the 1995 film version of "The Preacher's Wife" with Denzel Washington. Her later albums became less commercially successful, but she still appeared occasionally on film and TV. Houston was found dead in a Beverly Hills hotel room in 2012, at age 48.

input: Write a short biography of Whitney Houston.
